title: Bidens national security adviser says Russia sanctions announced week
story: Share this article Nearly a month into the war, Russian troops have failed to seize a single major city and their advance has been halted on nearly all fronts by staunch Ukrainian defense.Now Ukrainian forces are preparing to retake captured territory as Russian forces battle declining morale - according to the latest Pentagon assessments. A senior U.S. defense official also said Russian morale was falling.'We picked up some indications that some of their soldiers are suffering from frostbite because they they lacked the appropriate cold weather gear for the environment that they're in ... that they haven't - in addition to food and fuel - even in terms of personal equipment for some of their troops they are having trouble,' said the official.'They're having trouble and we picked up indications that some troops have actually suffered and been taken out of the fight because of frostbite. 'So yes, they are having continued logistics and sustainment issues.'

title: meet some of ireland s most innovative schools
story: The mural of plastic 12,000 bottle tops at Ballymoney National School, Co CorkChange is slow in Irish education. The Department of Education, irrespective of whatever minister is in charge, is generally more cautious and conservative than other government departments and teacher unions tend to resist radical change as well.And yet change – often led by schools and teachers themselves – is happening.One of the most notable initiatives in Irish education, DCU Changemaker Schools Network, which is run from the university’s institute of education, is holding a conference on innovative schools in Ireland on March 24th.“The pandemic has revealed the fault lines in traditional education systems and created an opportunity to reimagine education for 21st century learning,” says Fiona Collins, network co-ordinator of the DCU Changemaker Schools Network.Collins has been seconded to the DCU School of Policy Practice from her role as principal of Francis Street School, which is part of the network.“We support schools to network and foster the skills of empathy, creativity, leadership and teamwork,” Collins explains.“We support teachers and students in areas such as student voice, agency and participation as well as social innovation and active and engaged citizenship to address societal challenges such as inequality, climate change and mental health, assisting teachers and schools too.”Here, we profile just some of the schools involved in the initiative:During the pandemic, we all sought ways to make the most of the outdoors and, for many of us, that shift has become permanent.Scoil Bhríde in Shantalla – a Deis school just 15 minutes from the shores of Galway Bay and the docklands in Galway city – set up a “sea school” during the pandemic to ensure the children could avail of the amenities on their doorstep and get outside while still being within their five kilometres.Students here learn about marine life and conservation, marine biology, rigging and water safety, the effects of climate change and the skills of seafaring, sailing and fishing. They also learn about the history of traditional crafts and how to build a traditional fishing boat and they catch their own fish before cooking and eating it.It’s a hands-on, experiential approach that touches on areas of the curriculum including science, geography, history, art and maths.The school has also become a dyslexia-friendly school which focuses on the talents and strengths of the students as well as addresses the emotional complexities of dyslexia, with creativity in all disciplines as well as an emphasis on coding, self-esteem and emotional wellbeing.Empathy is one of the core values of the DCU Changemaker initiative, and the school has put inclusion at its core.“In November 2014 we established our first autism early-intervention class for preschool children, and we now have two early-intervention and four school-age classes,” says teacher Louise Redington.“Inclusion of autism-spectrum pupils with the mainstream is important to us, and the establishment of our autism centre has enhanced the learning experiences, empathy skills and social awareness of each and every member of our school community.”Student and teacher leadership at the school is fostered with an active student council.One of the suggestions from the children in the student council – to build an outdoor classroom made of recycled materials – was taken up, increasing the amount of outdoor learning, including growing vegetables in a polytunnel.Last summer, they were crowned “Incredible Edibles” champion after producing a bumper crop and successfully hatching chickens. As part of all this, the children learn about farm safety.“The teachers lead by example in how they act, speak and behave, and take on leadership roles in and out of the classroom,” says Redington. “Changemaker schools means we show empathy, creativity, teamwork and leadership in all we do.”No stranger to radical change, the school was the first to break the Irish norm of religiously controlled education school principal Miriam Hurley says they are constantly open to innovation.“In 2015, one of our teachers brought the idea of a forest school and, because Changemaker schools are open to listening to anyone with a good idea, we took it on.“We take the children out in all weather bar storms, and our families know to dress them for all weathers. It’s a very structured initiative that involves team games at the start, then free play within boundaries, and relaxation time.“We’ve had Halloween events, tea ceremonies, storytelling and inspiration from nature drawn from Irish folklore, and teamwork is a vital part of it all. There is huge creativity in it, with children using blackberries to make dye and landscape art, all the while learning about camouflage, sliding, hills and trees. They don’t even notice that they’re learning.”The school also places an emphasis on empathy, using restorative practices as part of its anti-bullying programme. This involves a teacher listening to both children in a dispute before bringing them together to hear each other.“Getting to know other Changemaker schools has been inspirational,” says Hurley. “While it can be a challenge to operate in an under-resourced education system, it is affirming to see children growing into critical thinkers and problem-solvers.”Our Lady’s and St Mochua’s, ArmaghThe only Northern Irish school in the DCU Changemaker initiative, this school places an emphasis on entrepreneurship.“For us, it means being open-minded and willing to embrace change,” says principal Gary Farrell.But, ultimately, Farrell says, DCU Changemakers means that every child takes on leadership roles, whether on their eco-committee or the pupil leadership team.They have adopted Roots of Empathy, an internationally acclaimed programme which sees children get to know a newborn baby whose parent brings them to the school over the course of a year and which has been proven to build up empathy.“Creativity is key too, and we’ve developed this in our children through digital storytelling and animation,” says Farrell. “Ultimately, all of these skills are what children need for adulthood.”Opening in 2006, St Ultan’s is a one-of-a-kind education and social care campus.“We’ve developed a system of integrated care and education through which our eclectic team – which includes teachers, special-needs assistants, social care workers, early-years practitioners, therapeutic staff and a wide range of service providers from each part of our campus – meet to discuss the needs of our children and collaborate on which responses we can offer,” says Gary Jones, school principal and campus manager.“This is not the typical way of working in Irish schools or youth services but the benefits greatly outweigh the challenges of developing a new model of working.“Most children arrive as infants and we get to know them and their families and provide the supports they need to flourish as they grow into toddlers and transition across the hall to the primary school. No child here needs to be hungry or lacking in confidence, and we cook meals on site as well as offer a range of additional activities including sport and music.”Despite its small size, this two-teacher school in west Cork has big ambitions when it comes to creative projects.The two classrooms much of spent the school year separated from each other due to Covid-19 restrictions.However, the school staff came up with an innovative project that would allow the students to work together while staying apart – a mural of plastic bottletops.Pupils, staff and the wider community collected some 12,000 bottle tops to create a mural of their community which stands at 24ft by eight feet.The mural shows the view from the playground of Ballineen Bridge with Enniskeane village and Ballineen village on either side. It features some of the wildlife in the area such as herons and swans.This mural, which turned rubbish into art, shows how a project can evolve even during lockdowns and how to be creative during a time of great challenge in schools.

title: work on charlemont metro station begins before planning application for line lodged
story: Construction work on the metro’s terminus at Charlemont alongside the building of an office block has already started. Photograph: Alan Betson Construction work costing €12.5 million has gone ahead on the controversial Charlemont link station near Ranelagh, Dublin, even though transport authorities have yet to seek planning permission for the rail line.However, work on the metro’s terminus at Charlemont has already started, which local residents say is pre-empting the statutory planning process and “locking in” the route for the line.The metro route published in 2016 was to run from Swords to Sandyford with a stop at Charlemont, currently served by the Luas Green line. US investment firm Hines sought planning permission in 2017 to redevelop the former Irish Nationwide Building Society headquarters on Grand Parade near the Luas stop. A condition of permission granted in April 2019 saw Hines required to enter into an agreement with the National Transport Authority (NTA) and Transport Infrastructure Ireland (TII) to accommodate a potential metro or light rail “on, at, or near the site”. Future optionsThe NTA had two months earlier decided to shelve the southern leg of the route, but said it would terminate the line at Charlemont and investigate future options for the southside. It said last November that any southside rail connection would not be built until after 2042, and would likely be a Luas rather than a metro line. Planning permission would be sought this year for the link from Swords to Charlemont, it said. Some 40 residents associations from across south Dublin have repeatedly called for the line to terminate in the city centre rather than at Charlemont, with motions passed at South Dublin County and Dublin City Council recently calling on transport authorities to identify a city centre terminus for the line.However, work has been ongoing since last year on the underground station at Charlemont ahead of the planning application. Enabling workA spokesman for TII said Hines had undertaken enabling work to allow a station to be developed at this this location in the future.Ciarán Black, of the CharlemontDartmouth Community Group, said that by commissioning construction of the station’s “exoskeleton” the transport authorities had “acted beyond their powers” and were “predeterming” the outcome of the planning process. He said construction took place “without ever notifying the public” and no site notice or advertisement related to metro works was ever displayed and no drawings were submitted as part of any application.Mr Black said sticking with the Charlemont terminus would prevent the future development of a metro to serve potential housing at Cathal Brugha Barracks in Rathmines, as well as Rathgar, Rathfarnham and the southwest city suburbs.“Whether intentional or not, the NTA is predetermining and locking-in their chosen route to all future decisions about metro extensions on the south side of Dublin.”A spokesman for the NTA said the Charlemont terminus “future-proofs” an extension of the metro along the Green line or southwest of the city. A spokesman for Hines said it has acted in line with its planning permission and put in place the requisite enabling works required for the site.

title: british and irish relationship should be based on equal respect says starmer
story: Labour leader Keir Starmer speaks to the Labour Party Irish Society Annual St Patrick’s Day reception at the London Irish Centre. Photograph: Stefan RousseauPA WireBritish Labour party leader Keir Starmer has called for a relationship between Britain and Ireland based on equal respect that acknowledges both governments’ roles as co-guarantors of the Belfast Agreement rather than simply consultees.He said the relationship had been dominated by Brexit in recent years but it had a rich and long history that was bigger than the current dispute over the Northern Ireland protocol.“And I felt they were some of the most uplifting years in my working life because there was so much progress going on, so much change going on. You could feel it, you could see it, you could sense it when you were there. And that has given me a really strong sense of the importance of that partnership.“The relationship requires respect, equal respect and understanding of what it means to be a country and to have that status, that friendship, that relationship and that respect.”Mr Starmer was speaking at the Labour Party Irish Society’s St Patrick’s Day reception at the London Irish Centre in Camden, which is in his constituency of of Holborn and St Pancras. Other speakers included Trade Union Congress (TUC) general secretary Frances O’Grady, Labour MP Conor McGinn, who chairs Westminster All-Party Parliamentary Group on the Irish in Britain and Adrian O’Neill, Ireland’s ambassador to Britain.Mr O’Neill said that this year’s St Patrick’s Day events in London had been conceived as a celebratory return to personal contact after two years of the coronavirus pandemic but they had been overshadowed by the war in Ukraine.“To some extent, we have to kind of dial it down a little bit or at least recognise that while we are enjoying this opportunity to meet in person and celebrate all the things that we really cherish, our democracy, our human rights, our independence, sovereignty, all of those core values that they are absolutely now being trampled on in Ukraine,” he said.“In Ireland, we’re working very, very closely with the UK, with the US with like-minded partners in the Security Council of the UN, within the EU, the Human Rights Council in Geneva, the International Criminal Court, using all the mechanisms at our disposal to isolate and increase pressure on Putin and his regime.”

title: britains borders open can let
story: Here's a paradox: Britain is a great country, say MPs, because it opens its doors (David Davis), but a mean one because Tory toffs don't want to let anyone in (Tim Farron). If you back the Nationality and Borders Bill, Mr Farron told the Commons, “you are voting for deaths in the Channel!” - and though Andrew Mitchell, leader of a doomed Conservative rebellion, didn't go that far, he agreed it was unkind and expensive.Rather than processing refugees in Albania, he said, it would be cheaper to “house them at the Ritz and send the under-18s to Eton”. And wouldn't that mess with the Left's head? They might think twice about open borders if the children were groomed to become the next Tory prime minister.To defend this “utterly obscene” piece of legislation (to quote a one-star review by the SNP), the Government sent in the lovely but unexciting Thomas Pursglove. As the MP for Corby, land of the trouser press, rattled through the 54 amendments sent by the Lords in a tone that sounded, perversely, like he was enjoying himself, Mitchell wandered the backbenches trying to foment a mutiny among those still awake - before plopping down insolently in the middle of the Chamber, waggling his red socked-foot provocatively like a red rag to a Bill.Pursglove finished. The rebellion began, an orgy of cross-bench agreement that Tory liberals and opposition socialists pretended to find surprising, but they're always of one mind on borders. Let asylum seekers work, said John McDonnell (that way he can tax 'em, the crafty old commie). Process them in the UK, said David Davis, where it is humane. Australia tried offshoring, said the SNP, and it didn't work. Oh yes it did, said Thomas Hunt of Ipswich, noting that the number of those dying at sea fell. Oh no it didn't, said Double-D, claiming that the scheme was judged costly and dangerous, adding that, in his view, what actually made a difference was “pushing back” the refugees - a policy the Left thinks is tantamount to murder.So, what are we supposed to do?When someone knocks on your door, say the wets, and begs for help, you don't turn them away. Amen. But if they pay a thug to break in via a downstairs window, says the Government, you've a right to complain.We need “control!” barked Sir John Hayes: yes to safe routes, no to the illegal. But while this Bill clamps down on criminals, it doesn't actually provide for new safe routes, which is akin to sticking a sign on your lawn that reads “All Welcome!”, while covering the garden path with mines and barbed wire.Mitchell noted that over 80 per cent of those entering Britain “illicitly” in 2021 came from countries that have no legal route. They're not dodging the forms. They're rolling the dice.The amendments were defeated, and the Government will be labelled heartless for trying to enforce the law, which is its basic job. “Disraeli observed,” said Sir John, “that it is easier to be critical than correct”. How true. But if only the correct course of action, namely protecting the border, didn't leave one feeling just a little bit crummy.More from NewsUkraine-Russia latest news: Russia could use nuclear weapons if facing &#39existential threat&#39, says KremlinLet civil servants work around the school run, says unionCouple charged with manslaughter over death of morbidly obese daughterTriple whammy of tax rises set to cost every adult £1,000 a year extraClimate change on the back burner as Liz Truss wants aid spent on women and girlsSNP costs taxpayers £150,000 after failed attempt to ‘redefine’ women to include transgender peopleMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: chris mullin birmingham six journalist reveal identity ira
story: A journalist who helped exonerate the Birmingham Six will not have to hand over his notes of an interview with an alleged plotter of the 1974 bombings to police following a legal battle.West Midlands Police attempted to use terrorism legislation to force Chris Mullin to disclose unredacted notes he made when interviewing a man – identified only as AB – who claimed to have been responsible for planting IRA bombs that devastated two Birmingham pubs.The legal battle centres on a long-running controversy stemming from Mr Mullin’s reporting in the 1980s on what became one of Britain’s worst miscarriages of justice.Six innocent men served nearly 17 years behind bars after being wrongly convicted of IRA bombings on two pubs in Birmingham, which left 21 people dead in November 1974.Mr Mullin helped expose the wrongful convictions through his reporting, including the 1986 book, Error of Judgment, which allegedly saw him speak to one of the actual perpetrators, on the condition he protected their identity, which he has done for decades since.The alleged plotter has previously been named in media reports as Michael Patrick Reilly, now 67. He was arrested by West Midlands Police and questioned at a police station in Belfast in November 2020, before being released under investigation.At the time, Mr Reilly’s solicitor said his client denied the allegations, including that he had any role in - or knowledge of - the pub bombings.Mr Reilly was named as a key suspect in the bombings in a documentary by ITV Exposure in 2018, which saw him deny involvement in the atrocity when confronted by a journalist in the car park of a west Belfast supermarket. An anonymous IRA terrorist who gave evidence to an inquest examining the deaths in 2019 said he did not remember Mr Reilly when naming others involved. On Tuesday morning, Mark Lucraft, the Recorder of London, said he did not believe there was sufficient public interest to force Mr Mullin to disclose his notebooks as it did not override the journalist’s right to protect his sources.Mr Lucraft said there would need to be a “clear and compelling case that there is an overriding public interest that would displace Mr Mullin’s right to protect his confidential journalistic source.“The journalism in issue was of the highest public interest value exposing serious failings on the part of the criminal justice system which resulted in the wrongful conviction and imprisonment of six innocent men,” he told the Old Bailey.“On this issue I do not find an overriding public interest to displace the journalistic source protection right. I decline to grant the production order sought.”Investigators hoped the material would help identify a surviving member of the IRA gang responsible for the atrocity.Mr Mullin said he was “grateful” for the judge’s decision.“The right of a journalist to protect his or her sources is fundamental to a free press in a democracy. My actions in this case were overwhelmingly in the public interest.“They led to the release of six innocent men after 17 years in prison, the winding up of the notorious West Midlands Serious Crimes Squad and the quashing of a further 30 or so wrongful convictions.“This case also resulted in the setting up a Royal Commission which, among other reforms, led to the setting up of the Criminal Cases Review Commission and the quashing of another 500 or more wrongful convictions.”Former Culture Secretary John Whittingdale also welcomed the judgment.“Whilst it is important that every effort is made to identify those who were responsible for the horrendous bombing in Birmingham, it is also essential that journalistic sources are protected if we are to continue to have a properly free press and therefore I do believe that this judgment is the right one,” he said.The relatives of the victims have called on police to prosecute those responsible for the IRA terror attack, and accused the force of using a court battle to distract from its failures.Julie Hambleton, whose sister Maxine was killed in the atrocity, suggested the legal battle was a “cloaking device... to deflect” away from police failures to secure convictions in recent years and urged the force to pursue a prosecution based on what they already know.“We want truth, justice and accountability,” she told The , adding that the court’s decision went as the victims’ families had expected. The news that police will not be given the documentation they requested is likely to dash hopes that the people responsible for the bombings will be prosecuted.Several men were convicted of the bombings in the 1970s, but were later freed from prison after doubts were raised about the initial investigation and prosecution.Mr Mullin was taken to court by West Midlands police who used the Counter Terrorism Act to argue that he must provide all documents relating to his work, including interviews with men who apparently confessed to being responsible.He had previously provided redacted notes, but in court, the barrister representing the police argued that the full documents needed to be disclosed to confirm the identity of the bomber.During hearings in February, James Lewis QC, who represented the police, told the Old Bailey that officers were confident they knew the identity of the alleged bomber, but the interview notes were crucial for a prosecution.He said that the journalist had conducted a four-hour interview with a man identified only as AB and made contemporaneous notes.The barrister described the confession from AB as voluntary, accurate and reliable, adding: “In short it is a full confession to the murders.”He pointed out that this was not a third-party disclosing information in the public interest. “This is the murderer himself confessing,” he said.Reporting restrictions are in place to stop the naming of two men in connection with the bombings. Mr Mullin has argued that forcing such a disclosure would be a breach of the principle that journalists are entitled to protect their sources. It is understood that the journalist removed the front page of his red notebook which detailed the inidual’s name and address in the mid 80s shortly after the interview took place, but he believes there are details in the notebook which could identify his sources if they were to be disclosed.  More from NewsCraven politicians are too scared to confront the true cost of electric carsUkraine-Russia latest news: Russia could use nuclear weapons if facing &#39existential threat&#39, says KremlinLet civil servants work around the school run, says unionCouple charged with manslaughter over death of morbidly obese daughterTriple whammy of tax rises set to cost every adult £1,000 a year extraClimate change on the back burner as Liz Truss wants aid spent on women and girlsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid inquiry ignores children paid ultimate price pandemic
story: The Children’s Commissioner has warned that the Covid inquiry’s failure to address social services will ignore the “terrible, ultimate price” that some children paid during the pandemic. The inquiry, which is being led by Baroness Heather Hallett, will examine the preparedness, capacity and resilience of the NHS, as well as the procurement of PPE, the impact of coronavirus on health staff and the use of “do not attempt resuscitation” notices. However, while the draft terms of reference for the inquiry have been published, they include just one reference to education and do not cover social services. The words “child” or “children” are not used.The public is able to submit responses on the UK Covid-19 Inquiry website until midnight on April 7.Responding to the publication of the terms of reference, Dame Rachel de Souza, Children’s Commissioner for England, called for the inquiry’s scope to be widened to explore the impact on social services because of a number of harrowing high-profile cases which “shocked us all and where the strictures of managing the pandemic evidently played a role”. Her comments come following the deaths of 16-month-old Star Hobson, who died of “catastrophic injuries” inflicted on her at her West Yorkshire home in September 2020.Following a seven-week trial, Star’s mother Frankie Smith, 20, and her partner, Savannah Brockhill, 28, were convicted over her death.Five referrals were made to social services by concerned friends and family in the eight months leading up to Star’s death - but the authority repeatedly closed the case.A joint statement from safeguarding agencies in Bradford said they “deeply regret” missing warning signs in Star’s case.The case drew parallels with that of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, who was murdered in Solihull borough in June 2020. The six-year-old boy suffered a campaign of abuse and was left with an unsurvivable brain injury at the hands of his father and his partner. In December, Emma Tustin was jailed for at least 29 years for Arthur’s murder while her partner, Arthur’s father Thomas Hughes, was given a 21-year sentence for manslaughter.The pair’s trial heard Arthur had been poisoned with salt by Tustin and subjected to regular beatings by both adults. He was also given punishments such as being denied food and drink and being made to stand for hours alone in a hallway.During the trial, it emerged social workers from Solihull Council had visited the boy’s home in the months before he died and found no issues, despite relatives raising concerns.Commenting on the Government’s Covid inquiry, Dame Rachel told The : “I have spent my first year in this role committed to putting the voice of children at the heart of recovery from the pandemic. “During it, many children had significant setbacks in their lives which I am confident we can, and we must, help them recover from but also help them flourish into the future. “That sacrifice they made to keep us all safe should be acknowledged. They have told me, in unprecedented numbers, they want recovery, and they want support in getting back to normal.“I think it’s what this generation deserves, to be heard and to be helped. It is also true that during this period some children paid a terrible, ultimate price, in cases that have since shocked us all and where the strictures of managing the pandemic evidently played a role.“I would be keen to see the experiences of children, and the effects on children’s social care, more widely considered than the current draft of the inquiry’s parameters currently reflects.”The  has been running a campaign calling on ministers to put children first as the country recovers from its Covid lockdowns.It comes after a group of MPs, led by Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Commons education select committee, called for the closure of schools to form a “significant part” of the Covid Inquiry.In a letter sent to Baroness Hallett, the MPs also asked for the impact of the pandemic on young people’s mental health and on their “life chances” to be considered.Anna Edmundson, head of policy and public affairs at the NSPCC, added: “The lockdowns left some vulnerable children and young people trapped in violent homes with little means of escape from the increased threat of domestic, physical and sexual abuse.“It is vital the difficulties, hardship and suffering faced by the younger generation over the past couple of years are fully examined and reflected upon in the Covid Inquiry, with the learnings that come out of it being used by Government to help those in need now and to ensure we are better prepared in the future.”       Helen Hayes MP, Labour’s Shadow Minister for Children and Early Years, added that throughout the pandemic “the Government has treated children as an afterthought”. “Vulnerable children were let down time and again, with huge impacts on learning, mental health, and wellbeing. The government’s dither and delay simply means this inquiry is starting far too late.”A Government spokesperson said: “Following the publication of the draft Covid Inquiry terms of reference, there is now an ongoing period of public engagement and consultation being led by Baroness Hallett to inform further changes to the terms before they are finalised. The experience of children is in scope of the inquiry.”More from NewsCraven politicians are too scared to confront the true cost of electric carsUkraine-Russia latest news: Russia could use nuclear weapons if facing &#39existential threat&#39, says KremlinLet civil servants work around the school run, says unionCouple charged with manslaughter over death of morbidly obese daughterTriple whammy of tax rises set to cost every adult £1,000 a year extraClimate change on the back burner as Liz Truss wants aid spent on women and girlsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: zelenskys address knesset fell flat
story: So bowled over were British MPs by Zelensky’s video address earlier this month that they topped it off with a unique round of parliamentary applause. In the United States, his reception was even more rapturous, with Nancy Pelosi performing a toe-curling poem on St Patrick’s Day, written by Bono, that compared him to Ireland’s patron saint (“he drove out the snakes with his prayers”).Not so in Israel. When Zelensky first asked to address the Knesset, the speaker, Mickey Levy, was hardly effusive. It might be tricky, he reportedly said, as the Knesset was undergoing renovations. This underlined Israel’s cautious stance on Ukraine. With Russian forces holding the balance of power in Syria, where Israeli pilots carry out regular raids, Jerusalem must tread with care.Nonetheless, Israel voted to condemn Russian aggression against Ukraine at the UN. And when Zelensky did finally deliver his speech to the Knesset on Sunday, it was packed. Even Benjamin Netanyahu attended. The Ukrainian leader has developed a trademark technique of citing imagery specific to his audience. He evoked Churchill when addressing Britons, for instance, and 911 when he spoke to the Americans. Each time these examples aided his argument. In the Knesset, however, Zelensky displayed the limits of his good judgement. His evocation of the Holocaust triggered a backlash. Yoaz Hendel, the Israeli communications minister, tweeted: “The war is terrible, but the comparison to the horrors of the Holocaust and the Final Solution is outrageous.” Others urged that Israel be judged in a broader, regional context. No Middle Eastern country other than Israel has condemned Russia. Indeed, ever since the Cold War, the Arab world has sought to maintain close relations with Russia while Israel has cleaved to the United States. The Yom Kippur War of 1973 could be seen as a proxy war between the two superpowers, with military supplies streaming in on both sides.Fast forward to this point and Israel has provided humanitarian aid to Ukraine, including the first foreign field hospital, which is being opened this week. It has also waived visa requirements for Ukrainians. In Zelensky’s eyes, however, this is not enough. In the Knesset address, he criticised Israel for not being more aggressive in its support. “You can mediate between nations but not between good and bad,” he said. “We can ask why we can’t receive weapons from you, why Israel has not imposed powerful sanctions on Russia or is not putting pressure on Russian business?” There may well be some truth to such criticism. Israel still refuses to supply weapons. But the country's room for manoeuvre is restricted by realpolitik, however much its heart weeps for Ukraine. National interest is a difficult imperative to ignore in any circumstance. But with a country surrounded by nations that do not believe it should even exist, it becomes a matter of survival. Perhaps Zelensky's failure to recognise this is what killed the mood most in the Knesset. Jake Wallis Simons is Editor of the Jewish Chronicle More from NewsCraven politicians are too scared to confront the true cost of electric carsUkraine-Russia latest news: Russia could use nuclear weapons if facing &#39existential threat&#39, says KremlinLet civil servants work around the school run, says unionCouple charged with manslaughter over death of morbidly obese daughterTriple whammy of tax rises set to cost every adult £1,000 a year extraClimate change on the back burner as Liz Truss wants aid spent on women and girlsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: brits face 8 price rises
story: Brits face % price rises in supermarkets this summer, says Cabinet minister for foodGeorge Eustice, the Cabinet minister for the UKs food supply, pointed to warnings that food price inflation could rise to % - and said chicken will be affectedA customer passes a sales display of oranges and pineapples in the fruit and vegetable section of an Asda supermarket Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar |commentsBrits face % food price rises in the supermarket this summer, the Environment Secretary declared today. George Eustice told the Food and Drink Federation conference price hikes in foods like wheat due to the Russia-Ukraine war could lead to chicken being more expensive.He told the Food and Drink Federation conference: I know that the Institute of Grocery Distribution have done a piece of work that assesses that food price inflation here in the UK could rise to %, possibly %, over the summer. “But itaposs also the case that itaposs very volatile, and dynamic situation. After his speech he told PoliticsHome the war “shouldnapost lead to a drop in supply”, but “itaposs likely that thereaposs going to be a cost pressure there thataposs going to feed through the system”.  He added: Speaking roughly, there are three or four very large poultry producers in this country. “They have a situation where feed costs account for around half of their input costs, and theyaposre seeing a cost pressure of around -%. “At some point, thataposs got to feed through the system.It comes as Chancellor Rishi Sunak prepares to give his Spring Statement tomorrow, with rumours he will cut fuel duty or raise National Insurance thresholds so workers pay slightly less - at the same time as the tax rises.Food poverty campaigner Jack Monroe warned earlier this month that the cost of living crisis could be fatal for some children. The writer, who secured theof cheaper lines of food to supermarkets after they were withdrawn, has warned inflation for the poorest families is even worse than official figures. She told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee: “The CPI measures is an average across a household basket of goods that includes, in fact, legs of lamb, bottles of champagne, bedroom furniture. “Nobody was looking at the basic range of baked beans, the p spaghetti, the p pasta. “When those things quietly disappear from the shelves there is no real recourse for it. There is no record that they were ever there in the first place and that then makes it dficult to identy that a £ a week food shop a few years ago gets probably about two-thirds of what you could get for that £ now. “That is not people deciding not to go to theatre and not have legs of lamb and bottles of champagne that is people deciding, ‘We won’t eat on Tuesday and Thursday this week, or we’ll turn the heating off, or we’ll skip meals.’” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON National Insurance Company Ltd.Spring StatementPensionsPrice risesInflationSupermarkets" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: government decisions made whatsapp deleted
story: Government decisions made on WhatsApp deleted many times, High Court hearsCampaign groups All the Citizensand the Good Law Projectsay ministers are breaking the law by deleting messages and using private accounts for Government business Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByTed HennesseyMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar  and the Good Law Projectsay ministers are breaking the law by deleting messages and using private accounts for Government business" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GettyImages-.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" and the Good Law Projectsay ministers are breaking the law by deleting messages and using private accounts for Government business" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GettyImages-.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" and the Good Law Projectsay ministers are breaking the law by deleting messages and using private accounts for Government business" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GettyImages-.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top" There are many instances of crucial Government decisions made over WhatsApp and other messaging services being unlawfully deleted, the High Court has heard.Campaign groups All the Citizensand the Good Law Projectsay ministers are breaking the law by deleting messages and using private accounts for Government business.Even Boris Johnson has used personal WhatsApp accounts to communicate “critical decisions”, the High Court heard yesterday .But Government lawyers argued ministers and officials used instant messaging apps because they need to communicate quickly with each other in the wake of the pandemic.Ben Jaffey QC, representing ATC, said the messages could serve as a public record for future societies”.And he said deleting them would prevent “scrutiny through inquiries or court proceedings”He said in written evidence: It is possible to identy many instances where messages concerning government business which were sent received using personal devices or accounts were never copied or transferred to any government system for archiving or records purposes, or were only copied transferred when there was a need to retrieve the message for some particular purpose.The court heard a Cabinet Office policy requiring messages be automatically deleted conflicts with the Public Records Act .From November , Mr Johnson was being sent confidential information via WhatsApp to his personal device, court documents argue.It was also said messages which were later screenshotted and published by the Prime Ministeraposs former chief adviser Dominic Cummings were never being recorded on Government systems.A witness statement from Sarah Harrison, chief operating officer for the Cabinet Office, says private devices are used by Government officials on a daily basis.Another witness statement from William Vineall, of the Department of Health and Social Care, said the Prime Minister, former health secretary Matt Hancock and other senior officials used personal WhatsApp accounts and email to discuss major government business, including the response to the Covid pandemic.Another said Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi has previously used automatic deletion WhatsApp on his personal phone for government communication.Mr Jaffey went on to say that at least one of the six top civil servants had used an automatic deletion .He also argued the actions of ministers and civil servants did not comply with their own policies.He said: The concern is the material is not being properly considered and is at risk of being deleted and lost entirely, and therefore meets the test of falling foul of their own policies.He added: The public has the right to see historically important public records, many of which centre around important policy relating to the pandemic.We say that these messages should have been archived and kept for future reference.  The Governmentaposs lawyers in written submission argued that there is no principle of common law stopping ministers or officials communicating in a way they consider appropriate.They continued: There is nothing intrinsically novel or distinct about the use of private email accounts, instant messaging and private devices.It was added: The claims advanced are detached from the reality of current working practices. The modern working age is defined by instant and fast-paced communications.This has only been enhanced by the pandemic, and the consequent legal requirements and the Government guidance, which necessitated the need for remote working, and in which context increased the need for fast communication across Government on urgent matters.Ministers and officials need to engage speedily and effectively with others.They went on to criticise the unreality of the claims made, saying they insulate the Government from the modern world.In their separate claim against Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the Good Law Project is expected to argue over the use of non-Government communication channels.As part of a dferent claim over millions of poundsapos worth of antibody test contracts, the GLP previously asked the High Court to order searches of former health secretary Matt Hancockaposs Government email accounts and his non-Government communications systems used for Government business - thought to include WhatsApps.The claims are due to be heard over three days before Lord Justice Singh and Mr Justice Johnson, with a decision expected at a later date.The hearing continues.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Sarah HarrisonDonald TrumpBoris JohnsonNadhim ZahawiWhatsAppConservative PartyAtc Inc.AppsCivil servantsPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: keir starmer calls government make
story: Rishi Sunaks top six Spring Statement priorities to help Brits beat Cost of Living crisisThe Chancellor Rishi Sunak is expected to tell Brits how the Government will help them get through the looming cost of living crisis when he delivers his spring statement on WednesdayKeir Starmer has called for energy companies to pay a windfall tax Image: PAByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsKeir Starmer has urged Rishi Sunak to announce concrete plans including a tax on energy giants in his spring statement on Wednesday. Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak is expected to tell Brits how the Government will help them get through the looming cost of living crisis. He has hinted he may cut fuel duty by up to p per litre, with forecourt prices soaring since Russia ’s invasion of Ukraine.The Labour leader backed the move – and repeated calls for a windfall tax on oil and gas companies to drive down soaring energy bills.He said: “Everybody is talking about how they’re feeling the pinch. They want to know that the Government is hearing them, that it’s going to do something about it”. He added: “I think the simple things are a windfall tax on oil and gas companies who’ve made more profit than they expected, use that to bring down bills.  “If the Government is going to actually do something about fuel duties, then, of course, we will support that because I think, for most people, this is such a dficult situation.” As households and businesses struggle, No  admitted that the Government’s energy security strategy had been delayed again to next week. Mr Starmer also said a planned National Insurance rise was the “wrong tax at the wrong time”.There is speculation Mr Sunak could scrap the rise for lower-paid workers by raising the threshold it starts to be paid at. The Resolution Foundation said boosting benefits would bring nearly four times more support to lower-earning families than scrapping the NI rise. It emerged last night pensions could rise by more than % in April  after the DWP insisted it “remains committed” to bringing back the triple lock – despite inflation rising.Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey will base the increase on average wages, .%, or September’s CPI inflation figure – whichever is highest.It will likely bring a bumper rise for pensioners next spring - but only after hefty real-terms cuts this year. The Resolution Foundation has said inflation could hit .% by September, higher than last year though still below a peak next month of .%. That would lead to a pensions rise of £ a week.  But the think-tank blasted the “rollercoaster ride” and urged ministers to ease pressure now Parents are also being squeezed by rising childcare costs and a drop in places, according to the charity Coram Family and Childcare. It found the UK-average price of  hours of care a week for an under two in nursery is £.. More than one in five people fear financial pressures will drive them into problem debt this year, debt charity StepChange found. Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Jonathan Ashworth claimed energy price rises will cause low earners and retirees to either “starve or freeze”. Below are six announcements expected on Wednesday: p fuel duty cut predictedFuel duty was frozen in October’s Budget for a th year in a row. But Tory MP Robert Halfon said it is “vital” it is now reduced as prices soar due to the Ukraine war. Mr Sunak has hinted it could be cut – amid speculation of p a litre. Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves said Labour will not vote against a cut but warned that p may not “rise to the scale of the challenge”.Inflation set to peak at .% Inflation is set to peak at .% in April after the Russian invasion of Ukraine made it even worse. Officials fear it could go even higher, beating the .% rate of . Some warn it could hit %. This will blow out of the water October’s forecasts that inflation would peak at .% this year and could rise to .%. It will mean more expensive food and goods, hitting the poorest hardest. National insurance to rise to .% National Insurance will rise from % to .% from April and will be paid by anyone earning over £, a year, up from the £, a year it is paid at now. There’s speculation the Chancellor could raise this threshold, taking some of the lowest earners out of paying. One Tory said: “If it’s about pride, they can now say Ukraine is the reason they need to change course.”Benefits to go up by .% Benefits will go up just .%, as little as £. a month on Universal Credit. In October the Chancellor cut UC for millions by £ a week.Pensions will also rise by .%. In a Budget “rabbit out of the hat” in October, he handed more generous benefits to . million working families by cutting the UC taper rate from p to p.But this only helps those who work, not the sick or unemployed.MoD budget to be increased Westminster sources told the Sunday Mirror the Chancellor is planning to raise the £bn MoD budget. One said: “Ministers are no longer talking about cuts. They see the need to beef up our forces to confront Russia.” It may reverse the cut of , troops to , by . But the Chancellor played down reports, saying he has led the biggest post-Cold War defence spending rise.Plan to wean off oil but not gas expected The PM is expected to set out an energy supply plan to wean the UK off Russian oil – but not gas – by the end of the year. It is set to invest more in renewable and nuclear power and aim for more oil from places like Saudi Arabia. But Mr Sunak is said to have called for a delay to assess costs of nuclear and eco power. The PM is reportedly frustrated with his refusal to back nuclear power plans.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Department for Work and PensionsLabour PartyTaxEnergy billsPrice rises" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: number kids school due covid
story: Number of kids off school due to Covid TREBLES in a fortnight in threat to exam gradesTeachers fear the soaring level of coronavirus-related absences could "seriously damage" exam grades as Tory ministers are warned ending free testing was "clearly a bad call" Image: REUTERSByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe number of schoolchildren in England off sick or isolating due to Covid has more than tripled in a fortnight, new figures show. In total, , pupils were off for Covid-related reasons on March , up from , on March , according to the Department for Education. Teachers and unions have warned the level of absences threatens to seriously damage youngsters exam grades and that ending free and regular testing in schools was clearly a bad call. The figures also showed an estimated .% of teachers and school leaders were absent on March , up from .% on March . Some % of all state schools had more than % of their teachers and school leaders absent, up from % on March , the data shows. It comes as school leaders scramble to help kids who missed lessons because of the pandemic catch up on lost learning. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leaders’ union NAHT, said: “These figures are absolutely in line with what we have been hearing from our members. Covid cases have been spiking again in many schools over the past week or so – in line with the rising numbers nationally.” Mr Whiteman said staff absences are “once again a big concern”, with the data revealing that nearly one in ten teachers and school leaders are off, “which is as bad as the very start of term”. He said many schools say it is “near impossible” to find supply teachers to provide cover, adding that “there is no doubt that this level of disruption has a negative impact on pupils”.  He said: “The Government cannot just let Covid rip through schools. Learners need and deserve better than that. Covid hasn’t gone away and we need a proper plan for how to live with it long term that is focused on keeping levels low and reducing disruption.” He said with “exams looming for many students this is a very worrying time”. He added: “Many schools are still finishing teaching the specications as there has been so much disruption over the two years of exam courses it is getting very tight for time already for teacher-led revision and exam preparation work. “More disruption now could be seriously damaging to pupils’ exam chances and education recovery.” Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, added: “These statistics chime with what we are hearing from schools. Once again, many are seeing very severe disruption caused by Covid, with high levels of both pupil and staff absence. “The improvement in the picture we saw in the national data in early March has proved to be a  dawn, unfortunately.” He continued: “Worryingly, this latest wave of disruption comes as students are preparing for exams in GCSEs, A-levels and other important qualications. It is an extremely challenging situation. “It is very clear that the Government must, as an absolute minimum, continue to make available free Covid testing for education settings after April , and that it must extend and simply financial assistance for the cost of supply cover beyond the end of this term, when the current scheme is due to end.” Meanwhile, Dr Mary Bousted, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, said the Government must change course on testing. She said: The Governmentaposs plan to end regular testing in schools and free testing in the community after this month is clearly a bad call. It will make Covid outbreaks and future waves hard to track and render impossible the efforts to anticipate trends. Without cases being picked up and isolated, widespread disruption in schools due to the virus will become an ever-increasing threat as we approach exam season. We have got to see a change of course on Covid policy from the top, with testing remaining free and at school level a renewed and much more far-reaching commitment to monitoring, air filtration, and other building requirements. It is only though such preventative measures that we can reliably keep education disruption under control, at a time when cases are rising. Living with Covid must not mean ignoring it. title: rishi sunak money pocket bother
story: things Rishi Sunak could do to put more money in your pocket - and why he wont botherHelping the poor requires knowing what its like to be one of them, says Fleet Street FoxMore money for poorer people  Whats the point of that  Image: via REUTERSopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThis week a man who has delivered more tax rises than any Chancellor of the past half a century will get up on his hind legs and tell you he wants to cut them. And then he wonapost. What heaposll do instead is slice a few pennies off fuel, and while you might think this is a dandy idea all it does is reduce the governmentaposs cut, and leaves the profits to oil companies who may, or may not, decide to lower the price you pay at the pumps.By cutting the cost of petrol and diesel, Rishi Sunak will take money out of the NHS, road repairs, schools, bin collections, social work, home help, and a thousand other things you donapost notice as much as the cost of a full tank, but need in order to survive, just the same.The fact heaposll do it while telling you heaposs making le easier for the average man on the street is a flat lie from someone who is at no risk of ever having to choose between filling up on fuel, or food. Itaposs classic Torynomics - the maths of keeping rich people rich, as opposed to making the poor better off.But what more could he do, the backbenchers cry. Vladimir Putinaposs put up the price of oil and gas, the pandemic has caused supply chain problems, and working from home has pinched the economies of our cities. Weaposve lost £bn of trade since Brexit, there are traumatised Ukrainians and Afghan translators to accommodate, weaposre full, weaposre broke, weaposre buggered. Plus, it isnapost easy, being green! There are some quite cheap and easy ways that he COULD put some money in your pocket, though. And heaposs not going to bother with any of them.. Insulate every home in the UK The quickest way of saving money on energy bills is to insulate your home. The rate of doing this has stalled, and while not everyone wants or can afford full net-zero compliance of the sort which Insulate Britain crackpots demand, it is possible for lots of us to do better -we had help. Cutting % VAT on insulation of any sort, plus the same for adding solar , wind turbines, or heat pumps, would make a big dference. Heaposs not going to, because itaposs not sexy, and why should you lot get something for less. . Windfall tax on the energy firmsShell is on track to post a £.bn profit this year, while BP is likely to make £.bn. Oil firms are taxed high already - %, compared to most companiesapos % - but letaposs face it, theyaposre at no risk of the workhouse. And it would produce a massive, immediate, undodgeable payday for government which could use it to bring down bills. He wonapost, for fear that it sets a precedent, which was the opposite of his reasoning when he said heaposd have to raise taxes because of the pandemic.. Raise the NI thresholdNext month everyone with a job, and every firm, will be paying more for the privilege. The .% hike Rishi will talk about is more accurately described as % - because NI contributions will be going up by about a tenth, from % to .%. Itaposs expected to raise £bn a year for the next  years, and will be given to the NHS to repair pandemic damage.But heaposs also asking the NHS to save £.bn in waste. If you think the NHS is currently wasteful, itaposs not clear how throwing another £.bn at it will help. If you think the NHS is underfunded, giving it billions with one hand and taking billions with the other also wonapost help. So whataposs happening is youaposre getting taxed % more for something thataposs not helpful, in any scenario. In any event, it should not be paid by the poorest. Raising the threshold at which you start paying from £, to the same as the income tax floor of £, would be fairer - and he wonapost do it because it effectively creates a tax-free basic income for everyone in work. It would mean less poverty, less disease, better nutrition, better health, and in the years to come lower costs for the NHS and social care, but why should the bleeding obvious matter a jot   . Make Brexit betterThe UK waved goodbye to £bn of cross-border trade with Boris Johnsonaposs bad Brexit deal this year, at just the time the effects were worse thanks to the pandemic and, now, the war crime spree in Ukraine. Thereaposs a simple way to restore every penny of it, though, which is to end all tarfs and customs checks by complying with EU standards on goods and services.It turns out, they werenapost so bad after all. And there is not a human in the world who wants to fill in  pages of customs declarationsthere is an option to not do so. This wonapost happen either, because it would involve a government built on hoods and ignorance admitting publicly that it doesnapost know the first damned thing about what itaposs doing, which would make Rishi look like the best economist while stood in a field of financial morons. Read more . Resign The worst Chancellors in British history are the ones who presided over growing poverty because they did not know what it felt like. They never went hungry, never shivered, never missed out because they could not afford to exploit an opportunity. The better ones did experience that, and knew the price paid for being poor - they knew that it led to sickness, squalor, worse workers, lower tax takes, public health problems and generational, national failure. They could see how hungry children led to lower GDP, and wanted to fix it.Little Rishi argued that feeding children was too expensive. He said helping the self-employed was too dficult, unless they were able to provide some PPE and had a Toryaposs phone number, in which case he happily threw billions at them, no questions asked. He didnapost have a problem giving visas to rich Russians, and now the government heaposs part of is rationing the welcome mat for poor Ukrainians. He seems to resent helping to keep factories open and Brits in work, sohe pulls POaposs freeport contracts on the basis itaposs fired a third of its UK workforce and employed Filipinos on £ an hour, realism itself will seek the therapistaposs couch.There are global, and dficult, economic problems to resolve. It requires someone with empathy, experience, and imagination to tackle them. Instead this chancellor will do tiny things - bijou cashbacks, petite lies, small-minded solutions that solve nothing. Thataposs why heaposs Little Rishi - thinks little, knows little, does little. The Spring Statement will be nothing more than Torynomics - bedtime stories from a man whose only real goal in le is to replace the party-mad pillock in Number , rather than nurse a nation back to economic health.Youaposll never get any financial sense from a man who spends £ on a coffee cup and £ on slippers.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PO CompanyConservative PartyBPEuropean UnionNHSBoris JohnsonVladimir PutinTaxEnergy billsOil pricesWar crimesCrimePoliticsSolar powerRishi SunakThe BudgetSpring Statement" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: russian oligarch alisher usmanov boasts
story: Russian oligarch Alisher Usmanov boasts about dodging UK sanctions on his properties and yachtA spokesman has claimed most of the billionaires property in Britain and his yacht were transferred into trusts before Boris Johnson imposed sanctionsRussian oligarch Alisher Usmanov, pictured here with Putin Image: REUTERSByRachel WearmouthSenior Political CorrespondentSam Blewett:,  Mar |commentsRussian oligarch Alisher Usmanov has claimed he managed to dodge UK sanctions by putting his UK properties and yacht out of the law’s reach.A spokesman for the billionaire, who has had ties to Arsenal and Everton football clubs, said most of his UK assets were transferred into trusts before Boris Johnson imposed sanctions over Vladimir Putinaposs invasion of Ukraine. Ministers sanctioned Mr Usmanov earlier this month because of his “close links to the Kremlin” as they seek to punish Russian President Vladimir Putin for waging war.The Government said he owns Beechwood House in Highgate, north-west London, and estimated it is worth £ million, as well as the th century Sutton Place estate in Surrey.But a spokesman, quoted by the BBC and the , said most of his UK property and his yacht had already been “long ago transferred into irrevocable trusts”.“From that point on, Mr Usmanov did not own them, nor was he able to manage them or deal with their sale, but could only use them on a rental basis. Mr Usmanov withdrew from the beneficiaries of the trusts, donating his beneficial rights to his family,” he added.  Sanctions experts questioned whether the Government would struggle to link the properties to Mr Usmanov under the more opaque and complex ownership structures. But the Prime Minister’s official spokesman said: “We remain confident these sanctions will have a signicant impact on Usmanov. I think of that there’s no doubt.” He added: “The sanctions against Usmanov were enacted with immediate effect, he cannot access his assets, it’s illegal for any person or company in the UK to do business with him. “And crucially, when it comes to sanctions, we are wherever possible moving as one with our western allies, so those that may be seeking to move assets will find they’re not welcome in the vast majority of the western world.” He was sanctioned alongside former Russian deputy prime minister Igor Shuvalov on March .At the time, Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said: “Sanctioning Usmanov and Shuvalov sends a clear message that we will hit oligarchs and iniduals closely associated with the Putin regime and his barbarous war.“We won’t stop here. Our aim is to cripple the Russian economy and starve Putin’s war machine.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Liz TrussVladimir PutinBBCBillionaires" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics spring-statement---big-"Martin Lewis warns Brits may have to choose between ‘starving or freezing’ByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe biggest cost-of-living crisis for decades is hitting Brits - and most of it hasn’t even started yet.As Rishi Sunak delivers his  Spring Statement tomorrow, pleas are mounting to help the millions of Brits who could soon have to choose between food and fuel.Energy bills, National Insurance and inflation are all surging in April, outstripping below-inflation benefit, pension and wage rises. Meanwhile tax and student loan repayment thresholds are being frozen in a ‘ stealth tax ’ squeeze on the cost of living.  The Mirror understands officials are braced for inflation to peak above % this Spring, with formal forecasts due to be produced tomorrow.Chancellor Rishi Sunak is considering cutting fuel duty by p a litre and is said to have looked at raising the National Insurance threshold, to take some of the lowest-paid Brits out of the soon-to-be-hiked tax.But heaposs resisting any bigger action like axing the NI hike entirely - or raising pensions or benefits beyond .%. Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis warned on Sunday: “I am virtually out of tools to help people now.  “It’s not something money management can fix. It’s not something for those in the lowest incomes, telling them to cut their bills will work. “We need political intervention.” So as we wait for Tory Rishi Sunak to deliver any help, let’s look at the biggest cost-of-living hikes he needs to deal with - and the dates they’ll hit. InflationDATE: NOWUK CPI inflation has already hit .%, raising the cost of food, energy and transport rises at the fastest for three decades.The war between oil giant Russia and wheat-producing Ukraine is now making this worse, with officials now braced for inflation to peak above % in April.It will mean the same pound in your pocket buys you less in bread or fuel, and tightens business margins to the point where firms could go bust. The Resolution Foundation expects inflation to remain high for most of this year and still be above % in September - a level not seen since the early s.  Interest ratesDATE: NOW Last week the Bank of England increased interest rates to .%, despite warnings it would “crush” households already drowning in the cost of living crisis.The Bank took the move to slow the economy down and cool soaring inflation . Governor Andrew Bailey recently appealed to workers not to ask for big pay rises, as that fuels inflation further. But it will mean new mortgage rates become more expensive, and inflicts an overnight rise to monthly payments for people on standard iable rates. Petrol pricesDATE: NOWPetrol prices have hit record highs due to Russia’s war in Ukraine, leading Chancellor Rishi Sunak to hint he’ll temporarily cut fuel duty.The average price of petrol reached .p a litre while diesel rose to .p a litre Sunday before last.A month earlier they averaged .p and .p a litre respectively. A family car with a typical -litre tank is now paying £.p to fill up compared to £. a year earlier.But Labour warned even a rumoured p-a-litre cut would make a dference of only a couple of quid to a family tank.And Mr Sunak would face pressure to make any cut permanent, despite Tories having frozen the duty for  years already while raising taxes on everything .Energy billsDATE: April The energy price cap will increase to a record £,-a-year for a typical household following soaring gas prices. Around million Brits on iable tarfs will be hit with a £ rise to the average annual bill overnight on April . Those on fixed tarfs will be hit by rises when their fixed-rate period ends. A second hike that could be just as big or even worse is expected on October . Rishi Sunak has announced plans to help, which include people living in bands A to D getting £ discount on their council tax in England, and a £ rebate off energy bills in October.But Labour has branded him the loan shark Chancellor as the rebate is effectively a loan which will need to be repaid over five years. Tory MPs say he must go further - for instance by increasing the £ discount or £ loan, or delaying repayments. But he was reluctant to announce help before April .  National Insurance riseDATE: April A £bn rise in National Insurance will hit working people as the Treasury looks to cut Covid backlogs in the NHS and begin funding social care.Employees will pay .p more in the pound on earnings above £, a year, a rise from % to .%. This earnings threshold has risen since last year, but only by .% - less than inflation. The Lib Dems brand this a stealth tax that makes Brits pay £ more.Those supportive of Boris Johnson argue the levy is progressive as the wealthier pay more.But Tory backbenchers hostile to new taxes baulk at the plans as the tax burden hits its highest in decades. While Rishi Sunak is unlikely to scrap the rise completely, there are claims he could change the earnings threshold - for instance, aligning it with income tax . Income tax ‘stealth tax’DATE: April Rishi Sunak chose to freeze income tax thresholds at a time when inflation is climbing at frightening speed. Youaposll have to carry on paying % on earnings over £,, and % on earnings over £, - just like this year. According to the Commons library, more than a million more people will be paying a higher rate of income tax by . And that was analysed before the latest rises in inflation. The IFS think tank now warns it’s a £.bn ‘stealth tax’, two and a half times bigger than first thought.  Real terms cuts to pay - including for NHS and teachersDATE: April Inflation means many planned rises to public sector wages - which are due every April - will be wiped out by rising prices. At this rate workers will need a rise of % to % just to keep up with rising prices, but the government is resisting these. Ministers have already spelt out plans to raise salaries for experienced teachers by only % in  . Health unions have also blasted plans to offer NHS staff in England a “miserly” % hike. The Royal College of Nursing is demanding % above inflation.  Council tax riseDATE: April  Most of England’s families will be hit with a Council Tax rise of % or more next Friday, Mirror research reveals. Of  councils that run social care, the Mirror found  were planning rises of .% - the maximum normally allowed this year. And a further  planned rises higher than .%, by using allowances that were unused in previous years. Now of course, most people’s council tax will be lower than last year due to the £ discount for Band A-D homes in England. But there are two big catches. First, that £ is meant to pay for energy bills - not absorbing the cost of a tax rise. In Rutland a Band D bill will go up by £, wiping out much of the £ discount. Second, the £ is a one-off. Next Spring, you’ll suddenly feel the force of not just this year’s rise but also the April  rise at the same time.Search for your council tax rise by postcode by following the link below. Covid testsDATE: April From April  the vast majority of people must paythey want a Covid lateral flow test - eventhey have a cough and fever. No has said spending £bn a month on free tests is not an effective use of taxpayers’ money at this point. This prompted a furious row with Labour, some medics and the Scottish and Welsh governments.Asymptomatic tests for NHS workers will be made available but not routinely, only as a surge effort where thereaposs an outbreak. But they will be available for care home residents. Exact lists of those eligible are being drawn up.Boots is preparing to charge £ for a pack of five. Student loans aposstealth taxaposDATE: April Millions will be forced to pay more on their student loans under what has been branded a “stealth tax rise”. Student loan repayment thresholds will be frozen from April  after plans to raise them by .% were scrapped. That means graduates will have to shell out more of their disposable income as wages and prices rise with inflation. The respected Institute for Fiscal Studies warned the freeze will cost £k earners £ a year more than they expected. IFS senior economist Ben Waltmann said it was “a further hit to real incomes”, adding it “effectively constitutes a tax rise by stealth on graduates with middling earnings.” It gets worse further in the future. Students starting university next year will begin paying off their loans when they earn more than £, - down from the existing £,-a-year threshold. And theof time to repay their debt will be extended to  years, up from . The IFS said this will leave poorer graduates paying £, more over their letimes.  Real terms cut to welfare benefitsDATE: April  Benefits will rise by .%, as little as £. a month on the rate of Universal Credit.Tory MPs pushed through the plans earlier this year - saying it was in line with inflation. But it’s only in line with what inflation was last September, before prices began to soar at an alarming rate. Many are warning that this will severely exacerbate the cost-of-living crisis for those who are struggling the most, with food bank use climbing. The Resolution Foundation has urged Rishi Sunak to raise benefits more generously as an urgent priority, ahead of any decision to cancel the National Insurance rise. Pensions are being cut in real terms - before rising next yearDATE: April Pensions could rise by more than % next April after the Tory DWP chief promised to bring back the triple lock - despite soaring inflation. Therese Coffey suspended the triple lock - a solemn manesto pledge - for one year in   because post-Covid wages were bouncing back in an “anomaly”.That sparked fury as it meant the state pension will rise by only .% next month, less than inflation. That is a real-terms cut of £ to Britain’s million pensioners, Shadow DWP chief Jon Ashworth said.But Ms Coffey said the triple lock wouldin   as promised. That could lead to a rise of .%, experts predict. A real-terms cut to childcare helpDATE: NOWPoor parents will be hit hard by April’s cost-of-living crisis as Tory ministers refuse to raise a crucial childcare allowance - despite soaring inflation. Parents on Universal Credit can claim back % of childcare costs, but only up to a £.-a-month cap - which has not changed since  and is not rising in April. Campaigner and working mum to a four-year-old and Gemma Widdowfield, , told MPs: “We’re all in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis. We’re all feeling the pinch. “My childcare’s going up slightly but the Universal Credit cap isn’t going up at all… that’s going to be passed on to us.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Spring StatementPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
