title: tories accused brexit stitch up
story: Exclusive: Tories accused of Brexit stitch-up after secretive donor-funded briefing dinnersFormer Vote Leave bigwig Sir Bernard Jenkin held nine private dinners, funded by donors, to discuss the Northern Ireland border row - and he refuses to say who attended the soirees Image: UK PARLIAMENT AFP via Getty ImagByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The Tories have been accused of at behind closed doors stitch-up after a senior Conservative MP held a string of secretive ‘briefing dinners’ on the Northern Ireland Brexit row.Sir Bernard Jenkin, who sat on the board of the Vote Leave campaign held nine private dinners, funded by Tory donors and held between late January and early March - some on consecutive nights.But the backbencher, who chairs Parliamentaposs Liaison Committee, has refused to say who attended the behind-closed-doors sessions.Three dinners were held in aposprivate residencesapos, with the remainder held in Parliament.And the almost £, bill for food and wine at the soirées was picked up by a pair of donors, according to Parliament records.Approached about the events, Mr Jenkin refused to say who attended the dinners because it would breach their confidentiality.He said: These briefings were about the problems arising from Northern Ireland Protocol.The Protocol is the temporary mechanism designed to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.The -mile frontier is the UKaposs only land border with the EU - and presented a seemingly impossible obstacle for Brexiteers.Naomi Smith, CEO of Best for Britain, said: Businesses and consumers in Northern Ireland have been doing everything they can to make the Protocol work while some Parliamentarians in London are plotting over private dinners, and the lack of transparency surrounding these secretive “briefings” suggests a Government stitch up behind closed doors.“A better use of their cronies’ cash would be to take a trip to Belfast to see for themselves the situation on the ground.”Jon Moynihan, a Brexiteer who also sat on Vote Leaveaposs board, paid £, towards the events, according to Sir Bernardaposs register of interests.  And Adrian RB Johnson, an investment banker, paid for £, worth of booze and food for the dinners. Theresa May agreed to the temporary Northern Ireland Protocol, which effectively places a trade border in the Irish Sea, in the hope that a solution could be found to keep the UK as a single customs territory without endangering peace in Northern Ireland.Mr Jenkin told the Mirror: I am pleased to say that there are now many more MPs from across the Party who are much better informed about the Northern Ireland Protocol.We are working together to find a solution to restore the Good Friday Agreement, while also respecting the EU internal market, and underpinning the Union of the United Kingdom.”In January, two days before the first event, Sir Bernard wrote on Twitter that the Northern Ireland Protocol could not be permanent - and was not protecting the peace process, but destroying it.And he has called for the protocol to be replaced with a system of mutual enforcement at the border, where the UK would guarantee there wouldnapost be a flood of non-compliant goods crossing into the Republic of Ireland from the UK.But it remains unclear how this would be enforced without additional border infrastructure.Sir Bernard mentioned he was organising the dinners during a meeting of the Commons Standards committee on February .But he told the committee the dinners were to discuss Britainaposs continuous at-sea deterrent. He said: There are entries going on the register. I am organising dinners about the continuous at-sea deterrent, and they are being funded by a Conservative donor.It is on the register. Even though I am just a pass-through, it is my dinner party where people are coming along and discussing the continuous at-sea deterrent, so it is on the register. title: universal credit amount 2022 payments
story: Universal Credit amount : Will payments be rising following £ cut in  The Universal Credit amount for  has been set and seems unlikely to change despite desperate calls to raise benefits by more than .%. At the moment, itll be a real-terms cut for millions of BritsThe DWP has been inundated with claims for Universal Credit due to the impact of the pandemic Image:UnknownByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar |comments Chancellor Rishi Sunak faces mounting calls to ease the cost-of-living crisis for millions of Brits when he delivers his Spring Statement mini-Budget on Wednesday. Benefits and pensions are due to rise on April  but only by .% - far less than inflation which itaposs currently feared could top %. That works out to be as little as £. a month extra on Universal Credit - a real-terms cut. It also comes just months after the Chancellor slashed Universal Credit by £ a week off the standard allowance, when he ended an -month uplt that was brought in for Covid.This anomaly is because benefit rises every April are based on inflation, but only on what inflation was the previous September.Because inflation has risen so fast since then, benefits have already been left behind.  Due to the time lag, itaposs likely there will be a big increase in benefits in April . On current predictions, it could be over % - which is the predicted inflation this coming September. But this will come far too late for families who are facing a cost-of-living crisis now. Charities and experts have called on Mr Sunak to shorten the time interval between the inflation measure and each benefits rise, or to bring forward next yearaposs rise. This would help stop the rollercoaster of below-inflation rises one year and above-inflation rises the next, the Resolution Foundation says. The DWP would argue itaposs already offered more help to people on Universal Credit.In a Budget rabbit out of the hat in October, Mr Sunak handed more generous benefits to .million working families by cutting the Universal Credit taper rate from p to p.But this only helps those who work, not the sick or out-of-work. Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves called for benefits to rise by the rate of inflation - which is .% now and could rise beyond %.She told the Observer: “The chancellor should look at how to uprate benefits in a fair way. They are supposed to go up by inflation and they are not at the moment. The Resolution Foundation says raising benefits would be the best way to help the poorest who face a cost of living crisis next month. An analysis by the Foundation compares the impact of three potential policies, all of which cost around £billion. They are lting all working age and pensioner benefits by .% rather than .% as planned offsetting the looming National Insurance Contributions hike for lower earners by raising the threshold at which they start being paid to £, and axing the .% rise altogether. The think-tank says raising benefits “delivers the biggest cash gains of the three policy options across the bottom half of the income distribution”, by a wide margin. That is despite many Tory MPs campaigning to halt the National Insurance hike, and very few by comparison campaigning to make benefits higher. The precious few who do argue for higher benefits say the current rate of Universal Credit is simply not high enough for a just society and leaves people turning to food banks. Yet Mr Sunak seems unlikely to raise benefits by more than .% because of the multi-billion pound cost - and the moral need to raise pensions and pay at the same timehe does. He might unveil new help in tomorrowaposs Spring Statement for rising energy bills but it seems unlikely to improve on the .% rise in benefits. So in summary - benefits are technically rising on  April , but due to soaring inflation, itaposs in fact a real-terms cut. The full rates are below. Universal Credit monthly rates NOTE: The following list shows the monthly rate from  April , followed by this yearaposs old rate in brackets. Standard allowance SingleSingle under : £.Single  or over: £. CoupleJoint claimants both under : £.Joint claimants, one or both  or over: £. Child ElementsFirst child : £.First childor second child and subsequent child : £.For the full list of DWP increases to benefits and the State Pension, visit the Gov.uk website. title: gp receptionist reveals hidden parts
story: GP receptionist reveals hidden parts of her job that people dont understandAn anonymous GP receptionist has posted online about her experience and responsibilities in her job after reading "rude and misinformed" complaints about others who do her jobA GP receptionist has had enough of hearing peoples complaints Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsSometimes when you work in a certain profession, youaposre forced to face unfair scrutiny for just doing your job. Some public-facing jobs tend to receive more scrutiny than others - such as police officers and parking attendants - but there is one role in particular that almost everyone has an opinionabout. GP receptionists have a dficult job. While those of us trying to make an appointment can feel frustratedwe arenapost given what we want or need, the person on the end of the phone probably has to deal with a lot of hassle. One woman who works in a GP surgery has aired her frustrations with the way sheaposs perceived by the public in a post on Mumsnet. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here The anonymous woman said she created the account specically to respond to the rude and misinformed comments sheaposs read on the site about GP receptionists. She writes: I have done this job for  years, it’s hard work but can be at times extremely rewarding. I work with a great team. But she adds that, contrary to popular belief, her job is about much more than just answering phones.  She writes: I deal with chemists, pharmacists, hospital secretaries, emails, post, hundreds of clinical letters and test reports, arrange all referrals, do all test requests, type all clinicians letters, new patient files are refilled, files from patients leaving must be found and ed, clinical letters received are scanned, coded and actioned, translators requests, letters to be typed up and patients to be called to arrange reviews, Imms, smears etc, the loaning out of medical equipment - there’s lots more but hopefully you are getting the idea that my job involves far more than answering the odd call. [sic] After reeling off the long list of responsibilities sheaposs tasked with, the receptionist makes the point that what patients see is just a snippet of what she does day to day. She also tackled the complaint that people often call for an appointment and are told thereaposs nothing available - but after a quick conversation they discover there actually is availability to see a doctor or nurse. She explains This is because I can put it down as an urgent call. If it is NOT an urgent call I will be reprimanded by my manager andthis continues I would possibly lose my job. The woman then opens up the conversation to readers, offering to answer their queries and complaints to help them understand her job isnapost always as it seems. She says: I promise any questions or comments will be answered in all honesty! I’m wearing my hard hat.Do you have a story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Hospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i spent student loan lip
story: I spent my student loan on lip fillers - I give up nights out with pals to pay for itAmi Maya, , from Devon, says most of her friends use their student loans to go shopping or pay for nights out - so she doesnt see the issue with using it to pay for lip fillersAmi has been viciously trolled for her appearance Image: @goatsxh   CATERS NEWSByNiamh KirkJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsA student with an addiction to filler in her face says she now uses her student loan to fund her habit. Ami Maya, , from Crediton in Devon, spends up to £ every single month on having injections in her lips and has also had filler in her cheeks, jaw and chin in the past. Ami, who was  when she had her first injections, now pays to have them topped up whenever itaposs needed - and it works out as an expensive habit. But with her student maintenance loan working out to just under £, a year, sheaposs managed to soften the blow of the cost, using £, of it to pay for her lips. She has even sacriced nights out with her pals to save money for more injections. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Ami said: My friends would use their loan for shopping and going out, but I use mine for filler instead. My friends would always joke that I was spending taxpayersapos cash on lip filler. I have always been into changing my appearance. I think big lips are such a trend at the moment. Ami said she most recently had a filler appointment in January, and had paid for .ml to be injected. But when the nurse tried to administer the injection she told Ami there wasnapost enough space for .ml, because her lips were already so heavily filled.  In total, sheaposs had .ml of filler injected over the years - and despite some vicious trolling, sheaposs happy with her appearance.Ami said: “People would always make jokes and compare me to Katie Price, and calling me a fish face, they would tell me to stop getting filler and tell me I am ruining my face.“It used to bother me, and I used to retaliate but then I became unbothered and would let it just go over my head. In response to the trolls, Ami decided to tackle their nasty comments head-on and make videos responding to the cruel jibes. I just think they’re sad people with too much time on their hands, she said. I do struggle occasionally with trolls I do struggle with my mental health and I had an eating disorder so I am already critical of myself so when I see people giving me their negative opinions it solidies what I think of myself. If anyone judges me for it, they’re not someone I need in my le.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cosmetic surgery" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: brave mum trapped under car
story: Brave mum trapped under car after hit-and-run saves unborn baby using her fingernailsAaliyah Lunn, , managed to claw herself and her unborn baby to safety after she was mown down by a hit-and-run driver in Stourbridge, West Midlands in Aaliyah Lunn and her son Shay both survived the crash in Stourbridge, West Midlands Image: Leila Coker   SWNSByBradley StokesLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A mum who was mown down by a hit-and-run driver and trapped under the car managed to save her unborn baby by clawing herself to safety by her fingernails.Aaliyah Lunn, , was with friends when she was run over by a silver Volvo which deliberately ploughed into a crowd of pub goers in Stourbridge, West Midlands.She was pinned under the car with the wheels spinning inches from her head while the weight of the front axle pressed down on her six-month baby bump.Incredibly, despite suffering horric injuries to her foot, Aaliyah saved her unborn baby by wriggling under the car. Driver Jack Richardson, , had smashed into the crowd in a targeted attack after shooting a love rival with a BB gun.  The shocking crash happened as revellers gathered to watch Englandaposs Euros clash with Scotland on TV at the Gigmill pub on June  last year. Richardson fled the scene but handed himself in two days later and admitted a string of violent offences. Aaliyah was left bed bound but despite her injuries she gave birth to a baby boy just five weeks after the horror crash. Last week she bravely attended Wolverhampton Crown Court on crutches and watched as Richardson was jailed for five years and three months. Speaking after the case, Aaliyah, of Stourbridge, said: “We’d gone to the pub to celebrate another of my friends who was pregnant.“We settled down, there was kids everywhere. At the time England were playing Scotland on TV so it was busy but everyone was having a great time. “Suddenly I saw Jack who I know through friends of friends. He pulled out a gun, the sound of this gun sounded like an actual gun but it was a BB gun. “He shot a man I know around three times in the leg. Everyone, including the kids at the pub, were running around screaming. “Jack left the pub and I went outside to go home but then this car reversed at high speed towards me.  “I tried to run up the stairs to get safe but I was too late the car hit me and just went over the top of me. “At first I didn’t feel any pain. I must have been going in and out of consciousness. “When I came to, all I could see were the car tyres above me still spinning. All I could remember was saying to myself ‘I am going to die and ‘what about my baby’. “I had no other option to wriggle myself further under the car to get free. “Both of my legs were totally numb and my foot was hanging off. I had to use my fingernails to drag myself from underneath the car.  “The car could have come down on me at any moment and I was screaming and shouting. “When I was finally out from under the car I just lay on the ground feeling my stomach but I couldn’t feel my baby moving. “I thought I had lost my baby and had lost my foot. I was drting in out of consciousness. I was just screaming ‘my baby, my baby, it is not moving, somebody please help me.’ “Then there were armed police all around me. My foot was in pieces, I had a seven-inch gap on my foot and it was hanging off.”  Aaliyah was rushed to Russell Hall Hospital in Dudley and underwent emergency surgery to save her baby. Luckily, the impact of the crash did not do lasting damage and five weeks later she gave birth to lbs oz Shay Bustin. Aaliyah, who also has a five-year-old daughter Sienna Mai, added: “I was put in the emergency trauma unit while my foot was being strapped up. “I had snapped every single nerve and tendon in my foot. It will never get back to normal. The main tendon that connects your toe to your knee cap was snapped in half.  “The baby at this point was stable. After the surgery on my foot, I was bed bound for six weeks and had to have carers four times a day.” Shay, who is now eight months old, now has a tilted neck and breathing problems as a result of the trauma suffered by his mum following the crash. Aaliyah added: “Because I was bed bound, and in so much pain, the baby had stopped growing and I could not have him naturally because my foot was still in a cast. I had to have a caesarean. “Where he was positioned in my womb, his one muscle on his neck is shorter than the other. His neck and head are tilted to the left.  “He is undergoing physiotherapy to try and straighten up his neck and still has dficulties breathing. “There are a lot of ongoing problems. He is constantly poorly. He may have to be transferred to Birmingham’s Children Hospital to help straighten his neck. “As for my foot, I still have to use crutches and there is not much movement in my foot. My tendons are still tight.” Richardson, of Stourbridge, flew into a jealous rage after seeing his ex-partner’s new boyfriend in the pub.  He admitted two counts of grievous bodily harm, two counts of actual bodily harm, possession of an imitation firearm with intent, possession of cannabis, driving without insurance. Aaliyah added: “Whether he was sentenced to  years, nothing is going to make me feel any better. The damage is done. I am going to have to live with that damage for the rest of my le. “I hate Jack for what he has done. My son suffered for the first few weeks of his le all because of one man and his actions. “I have been left with total damage in my foot, you could stab a kne through my foot and I would not feel it. “I am glad he is behind bars. It is what he deserves.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON VolvoHospitalsPregnancyCourt caseCrown courtRoad Traffic AccidentsCrimeGiving birth" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog who spent time staring
story: Dog who ‘spent all of his time staring at the wall’ unrecognisable in new homeTerrier Ralph was signed over to the RSPCA alongside  other dogs and was taken to the charitys Cambridgeshire branch to be cleaned up, treated for aliments and introduced to the outside worldRalph was one of  little dogs rescued by RSPCA Image: RSPCAByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsA terried dog who was so shutdown that he spent weeks hiding in his kennel staring at the wall has finally found a loving new home.Ralph was one of  little dogs rescued by RSPCA inspectors in October  when their owner realised they were struggling to cope with such a large number of dogs. The dogs had been kept in dark sheds and had had very little human contact.Inspector Justin Stubbs, who led the rescue operation, said: “These were well loved dogs but the number had just become too much for the owner. We worked closely with them and they agreed it would be better for the dogs to come into our care where new homes could be found for them.”to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.  The dogs had matted fur, fleas and were not used to being handled, and staff at RSPCA Block Fen Animal Centre, in Cambridgeshire, set about cleaning them up, treating them for ailments, and slowly getting them used to the outside world.Kennel supervisor Tfany Saunders said: “When Ralph arrived he was completely shutdown. He would squash himself at the back of his kennel and spent all of his time staring at the wall. He was very matted and covered in faeces and urine. “The team spent weeks just quietly sitting in his kennel with him offering him treats. Eventually, he’d come up behind us and take the treats from our hand before running away to the safety of his corner and eating them. He wouldn’t eat his dinner until night when we’d all gone home it was heartbreaking.” Staff continued and kept his routine strict so he’d only spend time with a few people who he slowly built strong bonds with.  “When he first wagged his tail as we entered the kennel it was so incredible!” Tfany added. Dedicated staff spent months gaining the dogs’ confidence and socialising them. Most of them needed their coats shaving off due to matts and many were suffering from flea infestations and ear infections. Tfany added: “The dogs had experienced little of the outside world and were all terried. They wouldn’t look at us and many would freezewe entered their kennel. Amazingly, like Ralph, one-by-one they each started to come out of their shell and really have flourished since.” The team slowly started to introduce Ralph to a harness and lead as he’d never even worn a collar before. Gradually they helped him learn how to meet new people and how to go out on walks, but the behaviour team knew they’d need to find very special owners who could continue his training in his new home. Sarah and Trevor Rix, from Norfolk, adopted Ralph in June , after he’d spent more than eight months working with the RSPCA’s dedicated behaviour and care teams.  Sarah said: “Ralph was a very timid, scared little boy when we rehomed him but with help of the RSPCA staff we became attuned to his needs and learned when to give him his space and when to encourage him to expand the boundaries of his comfort zone. With a calm and safe routine his behaviour gradually improved as his trust in us increased. “Ralph loves our other dog, Rosie, and she has helped him with some initial issues with toilet training and car travel. Ralph and Rosie love to go for woodland walks and we recently took the brave step of letting Ralph off the lead to run and play when we’re in safe areas he absolutely loves this. “Ralph has made lots of new friendsand has gradually overcome any uncertainty. Our regular acquaintances say they canapost believe how he has changed from a nervous seven-year-old puppy into such a happy, confident dog. “Ralph is a lovely little chap who melts the hearts of everyone he meets and is a favourite with all our family especially the grandchildren. He is a very sensitive and gentle character who may never fully escape his history but, every day, he brings love into our home. We feel the day we met him was the start of a wonderful relationship for all of us.” Tfany added: “It’s so wonderful to see how well Ralph is now doing in his new home, he’s unrecognisable from the frightened little dog who arrived with his friends almost  months ago during lockdown. This is what we do this job for, so dogs like Ralph can have the second chance that they deserve.”To help the RSPCA continue rescuing, rehabilitating and rehoming animals in desperate need of care, like Ralph, please visit www.rspca.org.uk give to donate, or call our donation line on   .Do you have a dog story to share  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. title: house hunting asian couple horrified
story: House-hunting Asian couple horried after homeowner banned them from viewingSareena Suman,  and her husband Ajay, , wanted to view a £, detached house but were flabbergasted when the seller told them they would were no longer taking viewings from the Indian and Asian community who are not serious buyersAjay Suman, left , with Sareena Suman, , were left horried when a seller refused to show them their property Image: Triangle NewsByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar A house-hunting Asian couple has told of their anger after a seller banned them from viewing a property calling Indians time-wasters seeking a day out. Sareena Suman,  and her husband Ajay, , wanted to view a £, detached house, but were told there are many other properties you can waste peopleaposs time on. The couple seen the four-bed house in Birmingham on the estate agent Purplebricksapos website and immediately fell in love with it. They messaged vendor Claire Devine, , asking for a viewing and were shocked at the response. The reply said: I am no longer taking viewings from the Indian and Asian community who are not serious buyers. But just look around properties for sale...as a day out.  There are many other properties you can waste peopleaposs time on so I suggest you go view one of them. The only information Mrs May had at the time she denied the pair a viewing was Sareenaaposs name. Sareena said: It has made me questioneveryone is thinking that about me. Do they describe me as aposThat Asian girlapos  Is my colour or my race a thing to describe me or stereotype me  The couple have been married for  years and are looking for a house to expand their family. Purplebricks have said they are no longer selling the property and have refunded the vendor fee. Mum-of-three Mrs Devine had lived in the house with her children and husband before moving to Sutton Coldfield two years ago.Mrs Devine told the Daily Mail aposthereaposs a lot more to the story than you know, adding Iaposm not the slightest bit racist.Sales trainer Sareena said she was in disbelief when she read the message.  She said: I had to read the message  times before it sank in. At first, it was laughable and I laughed because I didnapost know how to feel. And afterwards, the sadness kicked in and I got upset. “At first, it was laughable and I laughed because I didn’t know how to feel. And afterwards the sadness kicked in and I got upset. “Now, I’m not as angry as I was because I’ve come to terms with it but it’s just the shock I can’t get over.  “Where we live currently there’s a minority of Asians and it’s made me look at everyone dferently. I’ve never felt like that before. “I’m now conscious about what I’m saying andsomeone is looking at me. The couple have two children and have had to sit down with their eldest son, six-year-old Jhye, to explain racism to him. Sareena added: “I’ve always taught my eldest that words are just words. But I found that I had to have that conversation about racism with him. “The whole experience has made me scared for him.” Sareena was keen on the property because it was close to her family home where she grew up. The couple did not respond to the seller but reported them to Purplebricks. A Purplebricks spokesperson told the : The sentiments expressed in this message are completely opposed to Purplebricksapos views and values. As soon as we saw this comment, we told the vendor that we wouldnapost sell their house and refunded their fee. The house is no longer on the market with Purplebricks. We also contacted the buyer to express how appalled we were by this message and apologise that theyaposve had this experience. title: kate middleton compared lara croft
story: Kate Middleton compared to Lara Croft as she scales sky palace in Belize jungleThe Duchess of Cambridge sported £ khaki trousers as she prepared to climb the Mayan sky palace in Belize as part of her royal tour with Prince WilliamThe Duchess was compared to the Tomb Raider character after visiting the ancient site of Caracol Image: PAByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsRoyal fans compared Kate Middleton to Lara Croft as she joined Prince William on a visit to an ancient Mayan site in Belize on Monday.The Duchess of Cambridge, , was likened to the Tomb Raider film character after dressing down in khaki trousers, a white T-shirt and black sunglasses. Swapping her polished look for practical outdoor clothing, Kate channeled her inner adventurer and prepared to scale a Mayan apossky palaceapos deep in the jungle.The royal outing marked the third day of William, , and Kateaposs Caribbean tour with a visit to the Mayan archaeological site Caracol. Fans were quick to comment on how the Duchess bore resemblance to Lara Croft, played by Angelina Jolie in the films Lara Croft: Tomb Raider and Lara Croft Tomb Rider: The Temple Of Le. This is some Lara Croft and Indiana Jones energy. Love it, one person said. The Duchess is giving Lara Croft vibes in that outfit, another commented. I was thinking the same thing, a third chimed. Kate sported a simple John Lewis top, £ G-Star RAW trousers and £ Superga  trainers as she learnt about the history of the ancient site in the Chiquibul Forest.The couple marvelled at the ancient ruins, spectacular scenery and the countryaposs tallest man-made structure, known as the sky palace.Sharing a photo of their trip to Instagram, many fans compared the Duchess to Lara Croft who was famously played by Angelina Jolie.Kate and William were guided around the Mayan ruins at Caracol where they shared a giggle over a group of over-exuberant photographers.  The couple had lined themselves up for a picture in front of the ruins but the photographers had comically lined up at either side of them meaning each group was spoiling the otheraposs shot. As the camera crew expressed their frustration, Kate could be seen laughing with William who commented one sideaposs getting cross with the other side. Youaposre in each otheraposs photos. The pair are set to continue on to both the Bahamas and Jamaica later this week after their stay in Belize.  Their current week-long tour was planned as a kickstart to the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations as the commonwealth celebrates her  years as monarch this year. William last visited Belize as a teenager in  when he reportedly learned jungle survival skills with Welsh Guards who were receiving training from the British Army Training Support Unit as part of Exercise Native Trail. title: man caught massive stash bikes
story: Man caught with massive stash of bikes in back garden by Google EarthDetectives discovered the allegedly stolen bicycles at a property in Littlemore, Oxford, with a pile so big in the back garden that it could be seen on Google EarthPolice in Oxford discovered a mountain of stolen bikes in a mans back garden Image: Google Earth   SWNSByLauren BeavisLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar  A mountain of allegedly stolen bikes has been discovered in a manaposs back garden which is so big it could be seen on Google Earth.Detectives uncovered the mound of bicycles which were visible via satellite at a property in Littlemore, Oxford. Officers visited the house on Giles Road last Thursday when they spotted what looked like hundreds of bikes. BirdsEye photos of the garden show it full to the brim with bicycles while the grass is barely visible. A -year-old man who lived at the house was arrested on suspicion of handling stolen goods and possession of the criminal property. He was later released under investigation. Neighbours told how police were at the address sorting through hundreds of bikes. The wheels can be seen on Google Maps satellite images filling the garden. A Thames Valley Police spokesperson said: A large number of bicycles, believed to be stolen, have been recovered from the property. Officers are currently in the process of identying ownership of these bicycles.People took to social media to comment on the photos. One said: Cracks me up no one spotted it sooner. Surely youaposd think it suspicious to have a garden overflowing with bikes  Many agreed with this sentiment, wondering Did the neighbours not think it strange...  One person joked: What they got,  Kids and Counting lol  While others revealed the bikes have been there for years. Anyone with information about the incident is urged to contact Thames Valley Police online or by calling . The number of bicycle thefts in England and Wales fell to , in the year  to , according to the latest data from Statista. This is a % drop compared to the , bikes that were pinched the previous year. Thefts in England and Wales peaked at , in the year  to  and have been falling overall ever since. But average figures suggest one bike is still stolen every six minutes in the UK, which is equal to ten every hour or  per day. London is considered the number one hotspot for bicycle theft in the UK. Cyclists who have had their bike stolen are advised to contact police immediately with the frame number, cycle database number and a photo.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON BicyclesCrimeCyclingThames Valley Police" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: meet pork whisperer who adores
story: Meet the pork whisperer who adores the smell of meat and chats to her pigsAdrienne Eiser Treeby, from South London, is one of just a handful of women in the UK working as a charcutier specialising in pork - and cleans out dead pigs ears and intestinesAdrienne Eiser Treeby has been called the pork whisperer by her mum Image: Jam Press Hung Quach IIByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA woman who has been dubbed the pork whisperer has lted the lid on what itaposs like working as a butcher and meat curer. Adrienne Eiser Treeby, from Bermondsey, South London, is one of just a handful of women in the UK working as a charcutier specialising in pork. As a former professional chef, she decided to change jobs after meeting charcutier, Kris Doll, during a working stint in the US years ago. The -year-old fell in love with the art of curing and cutting meat so much that she trained in it for three years, all while working full-time to pay her bills.Adrienne, who is originally from Canada, said: My mother calls me a apospork whispererapos. I think at last count there are three of us running businesses like these – one woman in Ireland, one up north and myself in London. Meat is seen as an extremely masculine activity, which can make it a bit irksome when youaposre a woman. Someone once asked meaposa woman could actually do this workapos – to which I laughed and said aposwell, Iaposve been doing it for eight years, soI have any problems, I guess Iaposll let you knowapos.  Adrienne spoke about how she cleans out dead pigsapos ears and intestines. She said: Many years ago I had the opportunity to make sausage castings from start to finish, to which I helped clean the intestines straight from the pig, which involved a lot of flushing out the original contents. You can imagine what a pig might keep in there. Itaposs not for the faint of heart, I can assure you.Despite all that, I actually adore the smell of the meat aging. A bit cheesy, a bit tart, really tasty. I used to sayI could bottle it as a perfume and wear it, I definitely would!” Adrienne even names some of the pigs – as well as enjoying chats with them. She said: I helped feed and raise some urban pigs years ago that we named and [we] spoke to them plenty. Adrienne has revealed her top tips on how to make your own bacon. INGREDIENTSLoin, belly, jowl or collar of free range high-welfare sustainably-reared pork % of bacon curing salt per kg OR : demerara sugar to sea salt for a natural cure.METHODSkin the loin using a boning kne or ask your butcher to do it for you, and always work with the kne away from your body, as it is easy to slip. If using belly, sheet bone the ribs, keeping as close as you can to the bone, the bones can then be used for BBQ ribs. Trim off any loose bits of pork and straighten up the edges. On a tray, rub the cure thoroughly in to the meat, concentrating most on the flesh side, experiment with dferent sugars, spices and chilli flakes, depending on your taste. Ensure that all cracks and crevices are well covered. Place in a vacuum bag or Ziplock bag and refrigerate, moisture will leach out effectively becoming a brine, this is fine – just try to turn daily. The classic time calculation is one day per half inch thick piece of meat, plus two days, so a two-inch thick loin would be in cure for six days. Remove from the vacuum bag over the sink and rinse well under cold running water. Pat dry with a clean tea towel. Allow to dry in the fridge for two to three days, uncovered, it’s idealyou can hang the bacon so that air can circulate all around,not, place on a plate or tray and turn a couple of times each day. Once ready, slice using the longest, sharpest kne that you have, once your bacon ‘flitch’ gets too thin to slice, cut into lardons. Cook and enjoy.  Just because there is an end goal in mind, it doesnapost mean you aren’t treating the animal with love and care the whole way through. People are often surprised by the fact that Adrienne doesnapost eat much meat herself. She said: My daughter could eat her weight in our Pigtails – the name we give our snacking sausages – but outside of that, people are often surprised at how little meat I eat and feed my family.  I do genuinely believe that the way we eat meat needs to change and I wonapost eat pork, beef or lamb that I canapost be certain was raised in the high-welfare, the regenerative way that Iaposve come to believe is the only way forwards. Most of my family are actually in food as well – so itaposs less surprising dinner table conversation than you might think. The thing I find tickles me the most though and possibly doesnapost tickle my family, is that I specialise in pork and weaposre Jewish... so yeah, I suppose Iaposm the black pig of the family! Adrienneaposs job is very physical and required her having to lug huge weights of up to kg. Adrienne said: Charcuterie is genuinely a magical process but itaposs actually more about curing than butchering.  From carrying half a pig on my shoulder or hefting up kg of minced meat to dump it into our mixer, itaposs definitely a workout. But that said, I was still working right up till I went into labour with my daughter, so Iaposd argue anyone can figure out a way to do it! And like most jobs, itaposs only hardyou arenapost enthusiastic about what youaposre doing.  In , Adrienne launched her own company, Crown  Queue Meats, making British cured meats from traditional and historical British recipes. However, being a meat curer isnapost easy in , with veganism growing in popularity. Adrienne says she doesnapost want people to consume more meat but rather change the way they eat to reduce waste. She said: I honestly do believe that the way we eat meat needs to change, including reducing how much we consume and what farming practices we are willing to accept. That’s one of the reasons why I am so particular about which farms we work with, the business is low-to-zero-waste and why we’re so transparent about the process. My best friend growing up was a vegetarian and she was actually one of the most supportive [when I launched my business]. Understanding what you eat, and respecting it, should be everyoneaposs goals, whatever they choose to eat. title: mum gives birth baby weighing
story: Mum gives birth to baby weighing a massive lbs who wears toddler size clothesSarah Dines initially wanted a water birth in her home in without pain relief, but eventually had to have a c-section, partly due to the size of her babyMontrague Dines weighed lb at birth Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByBeth UreGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsA mum have birth to a baby weighing a hefty lbs. Sarah Dinesapos first baby, Montague, is now  months old and weighs in lbs oz. This makes him the average size of three-month-old baby as a newborn. aposMontyapos went straight into toddler clothes and now wears items for two to three-year-olds. Sarah, a teacher, initially wanted a water birth in her home in Broadstone, Dorset, without pain relief, but eventually had to have a c-section, partly due to the size of her baby. The astonished -year-old said: He was so big when he was born, he looked ridiculous.When the doctoraposs took him out, they were all laughing and I didnapost know why at first. One of them said he was ready for school, and the little towel they wrapped him just didnapost fit. He was in the .th centile for height and .th for weight. None of the clothes Sarah brought in for Monty fit when he was first born.She said: Even the little cap they gave him at the hospital was too small. My sister had to run and buy me some nappies because none of the ones we had fit him either. As heaposs got older heaposs gone up and up in sizes, heaposs always been in bigger clothes than his age. Heaposs a week off being one and heaposs in stuff for a - year old. None of Sarahaposs doctors can account for why Monty was born so big. Sarah said: After he was born we were both tested for gestational diabetes loads of times, but it was never positive.Iaposm  foot , and my husband Elliott, , is six foot, so we were never going to have a small baby. Neither of us were particularly big when we born, I think I just carry big babies. Sarah felt she had a large bump, but docs all predicted Monty would weigh around lbs. She said: All the scans were normal, so I was all set to go to have a home birth.  Initially, I just wanted to have a water-birth and that was going to be my own form of pain relief. Monty was  days late, so it got to the point where the doctor was talking about a planned c-section or inducing me. Sarah ended up needing to go to the hospital for an emergency c-section. She said: My water broke in the morning, and I was in full labour that evening, but I hadnapost dialated at all. The pain got so bad that I asked for gas and air, and then eventually we had to go into hospital. I didnapost want to be induced, and we had spoke about a planned c-section because he was so late, we even did all the paperwork. That ended up being useful because we had to go in for the emergency c-section, weaposd filled in all the forms. news uk-news mums-hysterical-screams-pet-dog-"Liverpool: Police confirm name of toddler attacked by dogByAlahna KindredNews ReporterHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A mum was heard screaming hysterically as her new pet dog mauled her baby to death.Bella-Rae Birch was just -months-old when she was attacked in her home in St Helens, Merseyside yesterday.Neighbour Jordan, who lives on a nearby road to the road from the family, said the babyaposs devastated mother Treysharn Bates was crying hysterically outside the house moments after yesterday’s horror attack. Jordan, who is hoping to go to university in September to train to be a paramedic, ran over to help when she heard screaming. She said: I gave CPR to the baby. My head is a mess. I heard them screaming for help and I ran over. The parents were hysterical. Iaposve lived here for eight years but Iaposve never spoken to them before.Have you been impacted by this incident  Email webnews@mirrorPolice were called at around .pm following reports that a child had been attacked by a dog at an address in Blackbrook, St Helens. Emergency services attended and Bella-Rae was taken to hospital where she sadly died as a result of her injuries. The dog was handed over to the police at the address and has been humanely destroyed. Shocked residents of Bidston Avenue in the town spoke of their utter devastation after the horric incident.Locals in the “quiet” road fought back tears as they fondly remembered watching the tot playing with her brother. Neighbour Joanne Matthews, , said: She was such a beautul little girl, toddling about. Iaposd see the family in passing, just to say hello, and they were always very pleasant. One resident, who did not wish to be named, said: “They were a lovely family, and it’s just devastating what has happened. “The dog had a stocky build, it was a Staffordshire terrier or Pitbull, and it was fully grown. There was only one.  “It’s devastating. This is a normal quiet street, and the children would play in the street. The little girl, a toddler, was always about. It’s a shame I won’t be able to see that again. Mourners gathered to lay flowers at the house, which was taped off this morning as police officers stood guard. Neighbours said that the family of four had lived at the house for around three years but had only recently purchased the dog. Another neighbour, who only wanted to provide his first name, David, said: There were absolutely loads of police officers, there must have been about  police cars and ambulances.  The square was absolutely swarming with them, Iaposve never seen so many police in my le. I was just in shock when I heard a baby had been attacked by a dog. I believe the dog was tranquilised in the house with a dart gun. Other neighbours reported seeing the animal brought out with a metal collar and rod by police officers. Speaking this morning, Superintendant Steve Brizell said: We were called by the family of a  month old girl Bella-Rae Birch, Bella Rae has lost her le in the most unimaginably terrible circumstances and our thoughts are first and foremost with the family and the wider community at this time.  Our specialist family liaison officers are providing the family of Bella-Rae with support and officers will remain in the area in the coming days to provide further support and reassurance for the wider community. Detective Inspector Lisa Milligan said yesterday: This is a tragic incident and our thoughts are with the child’s family at this devastating time. The little girl’s parents and wider family are absolutely devastated and our specialist Family Liaison Officers are providing them with support at this horrendous time. Whilst we are in the very early stages of the investigation into this extremely tragic incident we can confirm that the dog was only bought by the family a week ago and officers are working to identy the previous owners of the dog concerned and establish its history. Our officers will remain on Bidston Avenue this evening and in the coming days to provide reassurance to the local community and we will work tirelessly to establish the full circumstances. “If you were in the Bidston Avenue area this afternoon and witnessed anything, or have any information about the dog in question then please come forward speak to one of our officers. Our officers take the issue of dangerous dogs very seriously. Over the past years we have worked proactively with the five local authorities in Merseyside to ensure prohibited dogs are taken off the streets.“ The dog will be subject to further forensic examinations to determine the breed of dog and whether it is or isn’t a legal breed, the police have said. Officers remain at the scene this evening to examine CCTV, speak to witnesses and go door-to-door.Anyone with any information is asked to contact us via the social media desk @MerPolCC or aposMerseyside Police Contact Centreapos on Facebook, with reference . Alternatively, you can call the independent charity @CrimestoppersUK anonymously, on    or by visiting here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Merseyside PoliceCCTVBabiesHospitalsCCTV footagePolice carDangerous dogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queen-using-wheelchair-doesnt-want-"Queen is confined to a wheelchair according to Christopher BigginsByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The Queen is now aposlargely confinedapos to using a wheelchair, it has been claimed.The -year-old monarch carried out two virtual audiences from Windsor Castle today as Christopher Biggins said he understands Her Majesty is largely confined to a wheelchair. The Queen welcomed the Ambassador of Qatar and the Ambassador of Poland via video link today. The diplomats, who were at Buckingham Palace, presented the letters of recall of their predecessors and their own credentials at the audiences on Tuesday.Speaking on GB News yesterday morning, the actor, who has long been friends with many members of the Royal Family, said: “I have heard that the reason she’s not doing a lot of the events that she should be doing and cancelling them is because she is in a wheelchair. “She doesn’t want to be seen, she’s very proud. She’s our greatest ever monarch. It’s so very sad and I hope she is able to make her anniversary celebrations.” His comments were made while speaking with Eamonn Holmes and Isabel Webster. Asked by Eamonn about comparisons with the Queen’s late sister Margaret, whose appearance in a wheelchair at the Queen Motheraposs st birthday shocked the public, he claimed it was “embarrassing” for her.  Royal aides are reportedly anxious for the Queen not to replicate her sister Princess Margaret who was seen in public in a wheelchair, six months before passed away.A palace source said: Itaposs a haunting image and not one the Queen remembers fondly, William Tallon, the Queen Motheraposs page, then pushed Margaret in front of the waiting media in a wheelchair. Margaret was known for glamorous good looks that had lasted well into middle age. The world had never seen her like this. A source who remembers the occasion told the Daily Mail: The optics were terrible. It was supposed to be about the Queen Mother but all anyone saw was a sadly declining Princess Margaret. Last week, the head of state missed the Commonwealth Day service at the Abbey, a decision understood to be related to her comfort rather than a specic illness. But she has continued with light duties including some face-to-face audiences. Today, the Queen was onscreen and seen smiling and wearing a regal purple day dress. She welcomed the Ambassador of Qatar Fahad bin Mohammed Al-Attiyah, who was joined by Sheikha Raya Khala Abdulla Khala Al Khala. The monarch also received Polish diplomat Professor Piotr Wilczek. In just a weekaposs time, the Queen is hoping to attend the Duke of Edinburghaposs memorial service at Westminster Abbey. Large numbers of the royal family are set to gather next Tuesday, alongside Philipaposs friends, colleagues, representatives of organisations he supported and foreign royals to pay tribute to the -year-old duke who died in April last year. news uk-news royal-fans-left-swooning-over-"Kate Middleton and Prince William visit BelizeByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar |comments The Duke and Duchess of Cambridg eaposs first glamorous evening event of their Caribbean tour saw Kate steal the show in a beautul hot pink gown. But it wasnapost what she was wearing that caught the eye of some royal fans - it was Prince Williamaposs seemingly adorable public display of affection that left royal watchers swooning.The adorable moment came while the royal couple attended a reception hosted by the Governor-General of Belize at the Maya ruins at Cahal Pech, near San Ignacio.Kate teamed her a metallic pink full- dress from British label The Vampireaposs We with a traditional Maya embroidered handbag and sky high Jimmy Choo heels.  At one point the royal couple had to walk across some rocky terrain and down some steep steps - and footage shows William, ever the gentleman taking his we by the hand and guiding her down the steps to ensure she doesnapost topple over.A video of the cute moment was posted to Instagram - and royal fans flooded the comments section with how much the gesture warmed their hearts.One said: Helping her down the stairs, so sweet! Another wrote: He is a gentleman.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.While another added on Twitter : Honestly they are just so happy and joyful this trip, itaposs been so lovely to see them in Belize, just enjoying the rich culture and learning more about Belizeans. Meanwhile, during the reception last night, William gave a speech, where he said he was thinking of those struggling in Ukraineand added we stand with them in solidarity.He also referred to his children George, Charlotte and Louis and explained: Catherine and I have been deeply touched by the warm welcome Belizeans have given us.  We hope toagain soon and to show our children this wonderful country. They are rather jealous that they are not with us now!”It was a marked departure from earlier in the day when William and Kate dressed down in their casual clothes as they visited ancient ruins.The couple wore khaki trousers as they travelled deep into the heartland of Belize to visit the Maya ruins of Caracol, which date back to  BC. Kate teamed her trousers by G-Star, which retail for £, with with a simple white T-shirt and Supergra white trainers and gold hoop earrings. On the visit, she and William were given a tour of the site and had the chance to climb to the top and take in Caana, or sky palace, which remains the tallest man-made structure in Belize at ft. news uk-news sir-david-amess-unsettling-cctv-"CCTV footage of terror suspect’s ‘journey to murder MP Sir David’ByEmily PenninkRyan HooperRyan Merrield:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar Murder trial jurors have been shown CCTV of a terror suspectaposs journey to allegedly fatally stab Sir David Amess at a constituency appointment,. Jurors at the trial were shown the footage, after the suspect allegedly told the veteran MPaposs aide: I donapost think Iaposll take too long. Ali Harbi Ali, , making the near-two-and-a-half hour trek from his home in north London. He travelled along busy high streets and residential areas to Belfairs Methodist Church in Leigh-on-Sea, Essex, on October  last year. Ali, wearing a long, khaki coat and with a black, backpack slung over his right shoulder, could be seen appearing to assist a fellow passenger with directions as he waited for his connection at Barking railway station, according to the footage.  The Old Bailey heard he then spent about  minutes lying in wait, yards from the church building where he was due to meet Sir David, having duped his staff into believing he was a healthcare worker moving to the area and wanted to discuss local matters. Jurors previously heard that Ali had spent years hatching his plot, prosecutors said, researching a number of potential high-profile political targets including Michael Gove, Dominic Raab and Sir Keir Starmer, before settling on -year-old Tory backbencher, Sir David.  He allegedly stabbed Sir David  times with a carving kne with a -inch blade as he sent a WhatsApp message apologising to his family and friends, attempting to justy his actions. Ali then spoke to his worried sister on the phone for  minutes, as Sir David lay bleeding to death, before being apprehended by two unarmed plain-clothes police officers, who pinned him to the floor and arrested him, the court heard. Sir David, a married father-of-five, was pronounced dead at the scene.  On Tuesday, prosecutor Tom Little QC took the jury through a timeline of events leading up to the Sir Davidaposs death, including email exchanges between Ali and the politicianaposs aide Rebecca Hayton. On September , Ali allegedly emailed Sir Davidaposs office to ask about a meeting. He wrote: I will be moving to the area from a Labour-held constituency and wanted to get to know my future MP.  Since I work in healthcare, I would like to know his plans,any, for the hospital and workers. Also, as someone interested in Christianity, I have seen many churches in my area losing attendances and struggle with upkeep, eventually becoming at risk of being demolished or repurposed. I wanted to knowthe situation in Southend is similar and,so, what are the solutions.He added: Looking forward to seeing you soon. If all appointments are taken, let me knowthereaposs a cancellation. Iaposll be in the local area and will be able to drop by. Ms Hayton responded by requesting Aliaposs address and full name to check he was a constituent, jurors heard. Ali gave a postcode in Southend and told her: Iaposll be in the local area on Friday so it would be nice to see him regardless, although I know heaposs a very busy man so I can appreciate thataposs not possible.  Ms Hayton told Ali she would be happy to book him in for October . He later confirmed he was able to clear up my schedule and asked for an appointment at noon. He told Ms Hayton: I donapost really know how long the appointments are but I donapost think Iaposll take too long. Thanks for all the help so far.  The court heard that around the time of the attack on Sir David, Ali sent a message to family and friends which appeared to have been drafted days before, the court was told. In it, he said the attack was for the sake of Allah, jurors heard. He allegedly wrote: I apologise to my family for deceiving them for so long. I would have preferred Hijrah so as not to harm you but I could not. The obligations upon me to take revenge for the blood of Muslims were too great. The shame of abiding in the very lands that carry out these horrendous acts against my brothers and sisters was too much. Ali, from Kentish Town, north London, has denied preparing terrorist acts and murder. title: student 19 who thought freshers
story: Student, , given devastating diagnosis after thinking she had freshers fluThe -year old put her persistent cough weight loss and a hard cm lump that appeared above her collarbone down to leading a typical student lestyle.Zara Barton said her skin started to become itchy last February but dismissed it as a stress rash from a bad break-up Image: Kennedy News and MediaByLiam Buckler:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA student who thought her cough and large lump below her neck was just freshers flu was stunned to discover she actually had blood cancer. Zara Barton, , said her skin started to become itchy last February but dismissed it as a stress rash from an aposupsetting break-upapos or from boozing too much and was prescribed creams and antihistamines by doctors. She put her persistent cough weight loss and a hard cm lump that appeared above her collarbone down to leading a apostypical student lestyleapos. However, after the hives on her body became aposunbearableapos the fashion marketing and branding student pressed for answers and was shocked to eventually be diagnosed with stage three Hodgkin Lymphoma last November. The student had her eggs collected to help preserve her fertility before she started chemotherapy in December, and now, halfway through her treatment, she received the good news last month that there were no signs of active cancer in her body. The -year old is passionate about raising awareness of the symptoms of Hodgkin Lymphoma and urges anyone who recognises the symptoms to visit a doctor - and to keep ingtheyaposre not taken seriously. Zara, of Solihull, West Midlands, said: I thinkpeople recognise the symptoms, donapost hesitate to go to the doctors, evenyou feel like it is nothing because I just assumed aposit was nothing to worry about.  Something like itching, I didnapost have a clue that that was a sign of blood cancer. Itaposs best to double-check and you can tell when somethingaposs not right, even at the very start when I was getting the itching I just thought aposthis isnapost me, this doesnapost feel right. So itaposs important to be persistentyou still feel like something is wrong. Iaposve had so many comments on my TikTok about people with similar experiences of going to the doctors and not really being listened to and I guess thataposs because weaposre young and they just think apostheyaposre fit and healthyapos. The -year old said that her itching started last February and she visited the doctor in May where she was prescribed medication, which she hoped would solve the issue. However, it got progressively worse to the point where sheaposd scratch her skin so much it would bruise. In addition, she experienced weight loss and lost around a stone - but thought it was due to eating less. Zara said: Iaposd itch, which would then come up in hives almost anywhere on my body - so my arms, legs, feet, anywhere really.  It would literally drive me mad. It would be hot and was really getting unbearable. It was really persistent and there was nothing I could do to stop it. I had creams that I would put on but I remember sometimes Iaposd lie there with cold flannels and a fan just to try and make it more bearable. I put the itching down to multiple things. I did go through a pretty upsetting breakup in Mayand during that time had a bad stress rash, so I thought maybe that had continued. I thought being at university with constant late nights, drinking regularly, probably not eating as well as I should - these were just lestyle things that made me think at the time aposokI was eating more healthily, getting more sleep, not going out as much then maybe this wouldnapost be happeningapos. The -year old had a aposreally reactive swollen glandapos on one side of her neck which would disappear and reappear again for months. But she thought this wasnapost a cause for concern, given sheaposd previously had swollen glands from having tonsillitis and was at university where she assumed sheaposd pick up colds and illnesses. Zara said: When I first noticed it [the lump], I wasnapost alarmed at all. It was during freshers so I thought maybe it was a bit of freshers flu and could just be a swollen gland. I also noticed I had a cough which never really went away. I thought it was freshers flu. My friends all had coughs at around the same time, it was nothing really dferent compared to the people around me.I put a lot of my symptoms down to student le, especially with not being at home. My mum and I were sayingI was at home maybe we would have picked it up sooner but because youaposre so on the go you kind of just brush these things off. It was a bit dficult to get seen by the doctors as well as they were mainly telephone consultations. Theyaposre symptoms that you can so easily put down to something  and I guess I thought they were all separate issues. Zara said that at the start of October she found another lump above her collar bone and ed to the doctors, who she claims wasnapost concerned. However, at the end of the month, she saw another doctor who ran several blood tests and referred her for an urgent ultrasound scan. On November th, the evening of her scan, Zara received her diagnosis. Zara said: The doctor obviously didnapost want to have to tell me this over the phone but Iaposd been so persistent on finding out I couldnapost wait until the next day. He was like aposhave you heard of Lymphoma apos and I was like aposno, what is it apos He was like aposoh, itaposs blood cancerapos. Obviously that was just a huge shock. I just didnapost know what to expect, what that meant and what I was about to go through.He was trying to explain the treatments I might have. Obviously we didnapost know everything about it yet and we still had to find out what type and stage. You think the worst I suppose. My scan results came back showing it was stage three. It came back and showed that it was all in my neck, chest and in my spleen. That was quite scary as well finding out that it had got to that point without me knowing because I felt so normal in myself otherwise. After she was told that there was a risk of becoming infertile after chemotherapy, the student had an operation to remove and freeze her eggs in December. Ten days later Zara started chemotherapy at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham and has since had seven rounds with five more to go. She said that her itching stopped after her first session and has decided to take a year out of her studies, and will redo the year come September. Since her diagnosis, the teen who shares informative videos about the uncommon cancer that develops in the lymphatic system, said that the support sheaposd received from family, friends and even strangers has been amazing. Zara said: My diagnosis has affected my le a lot. I was living at university with my friends and literally felt the happiest Iaposd ever been, so I felt like Iaposd gone from my highest point to my lowest really. I posted my story online because when I was diagnosed I was going to tell my close friends and I thought people were going to hear about it anyway and when people hear that someoneaposs got cancer, you donapost want them to think the worst. I wanted people to know that this is a treatable type of cancer and I just thought that it wasnapost something that I wanted to hide, or be embarrassed about, itaposs just something thataposs happened. So I just wanted to share my journey and be open about it. I didnapost realise that Lymphoma is the most common cancer in teenagers and young adults and considering Iaposve never heard about the symptoms, I wanted to raise a bit of awareness in the process. I just wanted to show that you are still you as well when you are going through your treatment, youaposre not defined by a diagnosis. I didnapost want anyone to feel sorry for me, I wanted people to see that Iaposm still me. My diagnosis has put things in perspective - leaposs too short, just do what makes you happy I suppose. Zaraaposs dad, Lloyd Barton, is running the Brighton Marathon this April and is fundraising for the Teenage Cancer Trust, a charity that has been supporting her throughout her treatment.You can donate to Zaraaposs fatheraposs fundraising page hereRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CharitiesEducationHospitalsTeenagersFluCancerFertilityHodgkins lymphoma" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: teacher left crutches after being
story: Teacher left on crutches after being beaten up by five-year-old wins £, payoutAleksandra Aukettwas traumatised and suffered multiple injuries when "punched, pinched and kicked" by the reception class child in  while trying to keep orderAleksandra Aukett has been left on crutches Image: Champion NewsByGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsAn infantsapos school teaching assistant left on crutches after she was beaten up by a five-year-old has won a £, compensation payout after suing her bosses. Aleksandra Aukett, , was traumatised and suffered multiple soft tissue injuries when punched, pinched and kicked by the big for his age reception class child in  while trying to keep order. Ms Aukett, who stepped up to the witness box at Central London County Court using crutches, says she has been left with le-changing chronic pain and has not ed to work due to a fear of going back to the school environment in the aftermath of her ordeal. This week, she sued the London Borough of Hillingdon, the local authority responsible for overseeing the school, claiming more should have been done to protect her in the workplace. Today, on the second day of a planned three-day trial, the council agreed to settle the case, handing Ms Aukett £, compensation, as well as paying her lawyersapos bills. Earlier, her barrister, Gemma Witherington, told Judge Richard Roberts: Ms Aukett was acting in the course of her employment when she was attacked by a child known as X.  He had attacked another child and she removed the other children from the room to safety when X launched himself at her in the corridor and punched her in the chest and pinched her. He then kicked her in the hip and groin and legs. Ms Aukett told the court she still has a lump and swelling around her hip from the attack and has yet toto work. The boy - described as big for his age - caused soft tissue injuries to her lower back, chest and left buttock as well as long-term inflammation. Medical experts for Ms Aukett said she was resilient and cheerful before the classroom assault, but is now plagued by chronic back pain, PTSD and depression. Iaposm still restricted, she said from the witness box. Iaposm nowhere near the level of mobility, fitness and health I was at before the accident.  Her barrister said the child who went for Ms Aukett had learning dficulties and a vulnerable background and said her client fully accepted this. But this was a very nasty assault which had physical and mental health consequences for her, she added. None of her colleagues had warned her about the ladaposs violent tendencies, claimed Ms Witherington. The unruly youngster had a record for physically assaulting other pupils and staff, said the barrister, adding: it was reasonably foreseeable that this child would seriously injure either another pupil or one of the teachers. If Ms Aukett had known about Xaposs condition behaviour and or had relevant training, then it was more likely than not that she could have taken steps to avoid the attack, she told the court. In particular she would have been far more cautious going out into the corridor to calm the youngster and would have ensured there was more support. Lawyers for the London Borough of Hillingdon claimed Ms Aukett had been trained in how to restrain pupils and de-escalate incidents. And council barrister Roderick Abbott said it did everything in its power to safeguard staff and pupils from any risk posed. He highlighted a specic pupil risk assessment carried out on the five-year-old which pinpointed a risk of potential hazards, including throwing items and risk of injury to staff or other pupils. This clearly identies the risk of X being violent towards staff and pupils, he argued. Ms Witherington denied the claims that everybody knew about it at the school. But Mr Abbott told the judge that given the schoolaposs general awareness of the boyaposs stormy history it would have been impossible for Ms Aukett to be unaware of Xaposs behaviour. He accepted that Ms Aukett was the victim of a violent attack while doing a dficult job but denied that the school failed in its duty to safeguard her. However, after a day of evidence before the judge and negotiations outside court, the council today agreed to settle the case by paying Ms Aukett over £, compensation, as well as her lawyersapos bills. Judge Roberts commented: The parties are to be commended. Well, Ms Aukett, bringing a law claim is very dficult and proving cases is very dficult, but youaposve done that, so well done.Speaking afterwards, Ms Aukett said she was looking forward to opening a new chapter in my le.Itaposs been horrendous, she added, labelling the assault on her completely le-changing.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Court casecompensation" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory politician accidentally ate dog
story: Tory politician accidentally ate dog biscuits meant for Queens corgis, claims bookThe former health minister particularly enjoyed the cheese and the unusual dark biscuits until his colleague informed him that the Queen had laid them out for her beloved dogsThe Queen with her corgis Image: windsor.royal.family InstagramByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsFormer health minister Alan Johnson accidentally ate dog biscuits meant for the Queenaposs corgis during a lunch at Windsor Castle, a new book has revealed.While sitting next to Her Majesty, Mr Johnson happily tucked into cheese on unusual dark biscuits before his colleague Paul Murphy informed him the Queen had laid them out for her dogs.Royal biographer Robert Hardman has recalled the anecdote in his new book Queen of Our Times, where he shares the full le story of the Queen ahead of her Platinum Jubilee celebrations.Despite visiting Windsor Castle in , Mr Johnson, a Labour MP from  to , kept quiet about his dog biscuit blunder for  long years until he appeared on Channel  daytime show Stephaposs Packed Lunch earlier this month. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. During the show, Steph asked: You have eaten will all kinds of dignities and leaders and that in your time. And youaposve eaten with the Queen as well, havenapost you  Mr Johnson replied: I did make a faux pas. She was there. There were cheese and biscuits. Her Majesty was tossing some biscuits to the dogs, to the corgis. I didnapost see that, and I took one of those biscuits and put some cheese on it and ate it and was told, aposI hate to tell you, but they are for the dogsapos. The Queen has owned about  corgis and dorgis, a cross between a corgi and a dachshund, throughout her letime, starting with Susan who she received on her th birthday in . King George VI introduced a Pembrokeshire Welsh Corgi into the royal household in , sparking the Queenaposs fascination with the breed.  The dog, who was renamed Duke from Dookie, became an integral part of the family, even making it into royal photo shoots alongside then Princess Margaret and Princess Elizabeth II. It has been reported Prince Phillip aposloathedapos the Queenaposs dogs because they were too yappy - but this didnapost stop her from filling Buckingham Palace with them. Despite not winning over Prince Phillip, three of the Queenaposs dogs, Monty, WIllow and Holly, won over the nation after making their TV debut alongside Her Majesty and Daniel Craig in a James Bond sketch.Filmed at Buckingham Palace, the sketch became part of the  Olympic opening ceremony – and has since been viewed more than  million times on YouTube. Her dogs have also become the focus of their own animated movie called The Queenaposs Corgis, which stars Jack Whitehall and Dame Julie Walters as voice actors. The animated movie provides an insight into what le might be like for the Queenaposs dogs, and includes mention of the aposCorgi Roomapos, where the dogs sleep in elevated wicker baskets. She is known for giving her dogsapos unusual names including Bisto Oxo, Whisky, Cider, Spick, Span, Bushy and Brush. Her Majesty currently has two corgis, one of which is called Muick, a dorgi, named Candy, and recently welcomed a cocker spaniel who has been affectionately named Lissy. The four-year-old dog is the Queenaposs first gundog champion and means she has reversed her self-imposed year-long ban on new royal dogs. Gundogs, also known as bird dogs, are hunting dogs who assist their owners in finding and retrieving game. Lissy, who is listed under the official pedigree name Wolferton Drama, recently won the st Kennel Club ocker Spaniel Championship, seeing off  competitors to gain the top spot. Do you have a dog story to share  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.
