down after St Peter’s converted a penalty kick, skipper Mitchell having been adjudged to have brought down an onrushing midfielder.Souden then had a good chance double his and the Feather-sponsored Pupils’ goal tally after meeting Ryan Deans’ fine cross from the right-hand side of the box, but he couldn’t guide his cushioned header on target.The Pupils played the last  minutes of the match with  men when Jamie Burns was sent off for a tackle which was not malicious but was late.In believing that a goal-scoring opportunity had been denied, despite the foul taking place at least  yards from goal, the referee decided to show the Pupils defender a red card.This numerical advantage eventually paid off for the visitors in the closing minutes as a long throw-in was flicked on into a gaping space inside the box where a St Peter’s midfielder calmly side-footed a low right-foot shot into the net beyond Ferguson.It was a painful defeat for the Pupils, who acquitted themselves very well during the match and enjoyed spells of possession and pressure during the game, and in front of another healthy home crowd.However, their more clinical visitors took their chances when they arrived and managed to keep at bay most Pupils attacks in the second half to take all three points from Kintyre.Tomorrow , the Pupils host Glenvale FC, another Paisley side, in league action.Kick off is pm at Kintyre Park. For more information see @PupilsAFC on Twitter and Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: from our files march 11 2022
story: More than five years of ongoing time and effort to get an old school house in town renovated has paid off, as it is reopened as a bunkhouse.The old Free Church School at Big Kiln, Campbeltown, has been given new le as Campbeltown Backpackers and the first bookings have been taken.The Grade B listed building has two bedrooms, sleeping up to  people with Wi-Fi available for all visitors.The concept is designed to attract budget travellers down the peninsula as well as surfers and Kintyre Way walkers.It will provide more accommodation for the town#s major events like the K and music festival. It has already been reserved for the Kintyre Way relay race in June.The project has been carried out by the Kintyre Community Trust which is holding an open day tomorrow Saturday from am to pm.#There have been numerous challenges along the way, from brick suppliers who went into liquidation to the question of whether to put a pot on the fourth chimney,# said a spokesman for the trust.#This is a great project that has removed a bit of urban decay and replaced it with a new business opportunity that capitalises on what Campbeltown has to offer.#TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe row over school closures in Argyll and Bute is rumbling on with some councillors demanding a list of schools that could potentially be shut.Council leaders and education officials are still denying the existence of a #hit list#.At Friday#s finance and personnel meeting, the question of school closures was brought up by Councillor Sandy McQueen. He asked why the council had not issued a list of schools that would fit the criteria for closure.Kintyre councillor George McMillan said he couldn#t accept that there was legislation that could prevent a council from issuing a potential closure list.Councillor McQueen asked: #Is there not a way round this by putting forward a document with proposals that the schools may be closed #The Self-Governing Schools Act for Scotland  stops the council from being as open as it would like. The act relates to schools #opting out# from local authority control and it is feared that some schools will try to opt out to prevent closure.Council leader Dick Walsh said: #It would create real problems for some communities in Argyll and Bute and school boards would want to look at opting out.#He added: #The number of school closures depends on the budget meeting. It wouldn#t make sense at all to produce a list saying we are going to close all the schools when it might not be necessary.#FIFTY YEARS AGOThe MacBrayne#s* steamer service to Islay, Gigha, Jura and Colonsay will continue after its planned cessation date March .The news follows a public inquiry which was held at Port Ellen last month.After studying a report from the Transport Users Consultative Committee, Scots Secretary Mr Gordon Campbell has asked for the service to be continued until September .This will give him time to study the report and arrive at a long-term solution.A delighted Mrs Winnie Ewing, the former SNP MP who represented the islanders at the inquiry, said this week: #This is marvellous news. It means we have won. I visit Islay a lot and I know that to withdraw these services would mean tragedy.#And Lady Strathcona, the Colonsay landowner, commented: #We heartily applaud this decision. The Secretary of State took the wrong one last November.#The people on these islands will be very pleased to hear that he is going to consider alternatives and other methods during the summer season.#Said Mr Peter Wordie, chairman of rival group Western Ferries, which received a £, government subsidy last year: #This will not make the slightest dference to us.#We will continue to run the islands with the exception of Colonsay.#During last month#s inquiry it was claimed that Islay, Jura and Gigha would suffer hardshipthe service was withdrawn.It was also alleged that Colonsay, with its population of , would die.*Editor#s note: Caledonian MacBrayne, later CalMac did not did not come into being until  when the Caledonian Steam Packet Co acquired MacBrayne#s.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThe Clyde ringnet herring fishing vessel, Pride of the Clyde– owner skipper Mr Archibald Kerr, Tarbert – ran aground on Thursday morning just north of Skipness Point, Kintyre, in Kilbrannan Sound.The fishing boat Boy Danny of Campbeltown, radioed a message to Campbeltown and the local leboat, City of Glasgow, Coxswain Duncan Newlands in charge, proceeded to the casualty.The leboat reached the fishing boat shortly after am.The coxswain and crew managed to get a rope aboard the boat and pulled her off the beach.There was no damage and the fishing boat was able to make Tarbert Loch Fyne under her own power.While she was aground, the Tarbert boat Silvercrest stood by.The Pride of the Clyde was not fishing at the time. She had been out with the fleet, but had dficulty with her nets, so she was ing home from Ballantrae to get another net when she grounded in the heavy morning fog.Mr Kerr later stated that there was a sair wind and visibility was poor.He asks us to thank all who in anyway assisted or rendered aid to him and his crew that morning and so helped in the safety of the boat.The thick fog persisted throughout Friday, interrupting shipping and air services.The BEA plane services to Campbeltown were cancelled and all flying training at the Royal Naval Air Station was suspended for the same reason.

title: leader march 11 2022
story: One of the five tenets of taekwon-do is indomitable spirit.That is something which has been displayed in abundance in the last two weeks, since Russian forces invaded Ukraine.Despite all they are currently facing, Ukrainian soldiers took time on Tuesday, on International Women#s Day, to hand flowers to women they stopped at checkpoints.Viral videos of off-duty Ukrainian soldiers dancing in their unorms continue to flood social media.And, amid leading the fight against Russian invaders and holding meetings with world leaders, the country#s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, welcomed the start of spring in an outdoors video, ending the broadcast with a wink to the camera.The strength of spirit Ukrainians continue to show, from the bottom to the very top, should be an inspiration to us all.Kintyre has already shown incredible community spirit in its response to the crisis – well done to every person who contributed.And, although it might not effect change on a global scale, SG Taekwon-Do#s display of support for Ukraine shows that there are people in every corner of the world willing to stand up for democracy and what they believe is right.

title: letters march 11 2022
story: The Campbeltown Courier printed a story in February  about a painting, Village in the Valley, by H Shapiro.A reader then wrote to you, letting you know that the painting was by Hyman Shapiro and informed you that he had three children.I am one of Hyman Shapiro#s granddaughters. He had five children, not three.Before he was married to Gretl, the potter mentioned in the reader#s letter, he had two daughters, Gladys and Ruth, by his first we, Margaret, who died of tuberculosis.My mother Ruth, like her father, is a talented artist who has exhibited paintings.My we had to call the emergency services for me last Friday night at .am and,  minutes later, an ambulance arrived and the two paramedics provided me with great care and attention before transporting me to Campbeltown Hospital.I would like to thank them for the care and attention given to me.They do not receive as much gratitude from the public as they should and I would like to put on record my heartfelt thanks for their dedication and help in a very stressful period.Do the people of Campbeltown and her surrounding South Kintyre communities truly believe local frustrations are being heard in Kilmory Or have our three sitting councillors been napping this past decade, resting on their laurels, in the belief they are unaccountable to voters.It has been  years since the people of South Kintyre have voted in a local election. If you want to continue having the same conversations, raising the same issues, exasperated with the same results, thenthe same trio at the polls on May  and expect the same for the next five years.As a young man, I made a commitment to serve my country as a Royal Marines Commando now, I am prepared to make that same commitment to my community.I promise to proudly serve the people of South Kintyre to the best of my ability and present a strong new Conservative Unionist voice.If we do not meet on the doorstep in the coming months, can I encourage you to make your mark, on May , for a positive change to South Kintyre#s immediate future.I write after thousands of pounds worth of educational books were thrown in the bin in Oban.It is essential that our council#s leadership makes sure that hard-pressed council taxpayers are being provided with value for money. This in my opinion is a prime example of a failure to do so.The council leader talks a great deal about environmentalism but how is this environmental This is particularly saddening given the fact that so many teachers often struggle for ample educational booklets.My constituents are asking why our council taxes are having to go up when mountains of perfectly good books are being thrown in the skip It is beyond belief that this can be allowed to happen. These expensive books could be put to much better use than this.

title: pupils u17s return to kintyre with well earned point
story: Campbeltown Pupils YFC sed to Kintyre on Sunday night happy with a point after an eventful Glasgow and District Youth Football League encounter against Rutherglen Glencairn.Played at the Toryglen Regional Centre in basking sunshine more akin to a summer’s day, the young Pupils team got off to a poor start and found themselves - down after five minutes.The visitors really struggled to get to grips with the game in the opening  minutes but eventually found some rhythm and started to control the game.After  minutes, Stuart Phillips equalised with a cracking right foot finish into the top hand corner from  yards out.With five minutes of the half remaining, Calum Ellis made it - to the Pupils with a well-executed goal.As the first half drew to a close there looked to be only one winner, with the Pupils dominating the game.As in the first half, the Pupils started the second half slowly and it was the Glasgow side who dominated and made it - in the nd minute with a cracking goal.The Pupils, uncharacteristically, lost their way and Rutherglen made it - in the st minute from the penalty spot.Six minutes later, it easily could have been - but for heroic defending and goalkeeping from Ryan Harding and Lorne Paterson.With  minutes left, things went from bad to worse as Graham saw red for his second yellow card of the game and the Ardshiel Hotel-sponsored side were reduced to  men and trailing by a goal.A switch was badly needed and Scott Oman was introduced in goal with the Pupils going to a back three of Kyle Paterson, Josh Arkell and Euan Dott, with Lorne Paterson moving from goal into the centre of midfield with Kyle Danson.Ironically, the Pupils started to play their best football of the half and deservedly equalised with  minutes remaining.A penalty was awarded and Ellis made no mistake from  yards to make it -.With five minutes remaining, Ryan Shields had a great opportunity to take the lead but there was no more scoring and the Pupils should be happy with their point.This Sunday , the s host St Patrick#s in league business with a midday kick-off on the G AWP, Kinloch Green.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  – questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement – a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write ‘a piece’ for this newspaper. The questions weren’t so much about me but you – who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about ‘me’ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I don’t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity – from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity – a simplication, I know – and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: mica gets the chop for charities
story: The Dalintober Primary School pupil is donating her cut hair to the Little Princess Trust, to help make wigs for children and young people affected by hair loss, and she is donating money raised through sponsorship to Comic Relief.In , Mica#s family moved to Campbeltown from Peru, where it#s common for girls to have very long hair.#Mica has wanted her hair cut for ages, for maybe three years, since before she came to Scotland,# explained her mum Elizabeth. #She is very sporty and, so, a shorter haircut is much easier for her to manage.#She didn’t want her hair to go to waste and thought maybe it could benefit other children who have illnesses that make their hair fall out or those having cancer treatment.#Mica also decided to raise money for charity and chose Comic Relief because funds raised are spent helping poor and disadvantaged people both in the UK and in the world’s poorest communities.Gayle Durnin at Gloss Hair did the honours on Tuesday, March , turning Mica#s long do into a sleek bob. She very kindly did not charge for the haircut as a donation to the cause.The last time Mica had short hair was when she was an infant but despite the big change, she is very pleased with her decision.#She wasn#t scared, only happy,# Elizabeth said. #She has only ever had her hair slightly trimmed in her letime and it was probably at its longest during lockdown. She is very excited about the change of look.#Elizabeth added: #Mica wanted her hair cut and her dad and I are extremely proud that she wasn#t just thinking entirely about herself but thought about how she could use her haircut as an opportunity to help benefit other children.#The money she is raising for Comic Relief will help so many disadvantaged children in this country, abroad and, of course, in Ukraine.#We think how grateful we are to be able to live in a peaceful country, while, for many, simple activities like getting a haircut are secondary to basic survival.#Mica has already smashed her initial fundraising target of £, raising an incredible £ on her JustGiving page, but she would welcome any additional donations.Visit justgiving fundraising elizabeth-nimmo-de-amaut to donate.#Thank you to everyone who has donated so far,# said Elizabeth, #Mica really never expected to raise so much just from a haircut.#

title: wrestler iona sky takes down london lovelust
story: The Tarbert Academy pupil won despite interference from LoveLust#s manager, but at what cost Afterwards, the punk rock princess donned a plaid shirt and moved to the dark side of the company, joining the nefarious Struthers Sisters and beatdown LoveLust.At the end of the show, the Struthers faction, including Sky, were kept from entering the ring and it looks like wrestling fans could be in for a power struggle between the House Of LoveLust and The Struthers Family in Renegade Wrestling – dangerous times!Sky did all this the day after she and fellow Tarbert Academy pupil Guthrie Scott supported music sensations Peat and Diesel at their sold-out Tarbert show on Friday night with their band Anavrin.

title: bowlers at twos and threes in the clubhouse
story: Members have been warming up for the outdoor season with a iety of carpet bowls competitions in the comfort of their own clubhouse.On February  the first winter competition was held for the Archie Morans Triples Cup and this was won by Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard.On Saturday the final of the Gilchrist Joiners sponsored Open Pairs was contested and after a competitive three nights two father-and-son pairings progressed to vie for the title.The pairings of Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.The final was closely contested with Jimmy and Craig coming out winners.Organisers congratulated Jimmy and Craig who proved worthy winners and thanked everyone who took part over the week along with new sponsor Gilchrist Joiners.Pic caps: Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard lted the Archie Morans Triples Cup.

title: photograph of the week march 11 2022 2
story: Since the beginning of lockdown Jane has been going out and about with her Galaxy Tablet collecting scenic shots from all over the island. What#s more there are no filters or any tampering whatsoever in her photographs.Just the natural beauty of the West Coast.

title: dogged display on the dunaverty course
story: In the first group out Katharine Hardman played a steady game, despite an unaccompanied dog joining the group on the th green and temporarily pinching her ball.Even with the best endeavours of the dog to disrupt the next couple of holes and increasing wind, Katharine carded a respectable and took the lead.The second group also had to contend with the dog for a couple of holes but this did not deter Eleanor Hawkins who also matched Katharine#s score, but as she had a better inward half took first place.Result: , Eleanor Hawkins #  , Katharine Hardman # , Katie Cappello # .

title: climate change call
story: Stan Phillips gave the stark warning to community chiefs after the International Panel on Climate Changepublished a report saying climate change was worse than predicted.Mr Phillips is chairman of a short le working group set up by Argyll and Bute Community Planning Partnership , which held a virtual meeting on Wednesday  March .Alok Sharma, the UK president of the UN climate talks, was among those who urged faster action when the report was published.Mr Phillips, who works for NatureScot and lives in Lochgilphead, now hopes to find funding to invest in a project officer post.He told the meeting: #On February , a report came out stating that in terms of climate change, things are way worse than we thought.#I was pretty sure that report would have occupied headlines over the past couple of weeks, but because of the conflict in Ukraine, it has not had much of a look-in.#So the message is we need to go much further and faster on climate change action. We have spent the last couple of months working with other parties to see how they work.#It is clear we need to employ at least one person as project officer to work up plans for climate change engagement in Argyll and Bute.#We assume it costs £, to set up one post for one year, and that is a lot of money to find, so we have started looking for funds already.#Mr Phillips added: #This affects the council, its roads and infrastructure and will affect health and welfare, due to many issues, not least fuel price rises.#Every group in Argyll and Bute is going to have to consider how they will transform themselves into a carbon neutral business.#It is a task for all of us and I am formally asking us all to go and find finance to take this project forward. I said it was coming and this is the day.#Joe McKay, chairman of the CPP, who works for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, replied: #I can help you out with some fundingwe speak off the table.#I am not promising a large amount but I can help you outwe were quick. There is also a plan in place for electric charging points at all of my stations.#

title: from our files friday march 18
story: Friday March  Gigha was alive yesterday, Thursday, as people travelled to join in the celebrations for its th anniversary of community ownership.Campbeltown Junior Pipe Band piped the children from the local primary school down the main road to the hotel to emphasise the change in the number of children on the island.The children donned their new unorms to mark the occasion, carrying the Gigha flag.Fundraising has been ongoing over a period of time to raise cash towards the celebrations.To date more than £, has been raised, and events have included a race night, celebrations at New Year, and a quiz night.Last night islanders gathered for the ceilidh to bring the celebrations to a close.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOFriday March  Argyll’s newest nursing home was officially opened in Campbeltown.The £, Kintyre Nursing Home, which is situated in Hall Street overlooking Campbeltown Loch, was formally opened by Councillor George McMillan.Speaking during the opening of the new home, Mr McMillan said thatthe care in the home was as good as the building itself, no one would have anything to worry about.He went on to explain that getting the home build have not always been an easy task.‘There were some dficulties about the site because of the ground conditions but there were also other problems with the planners about this site because it’s a very prominent site and it’s next door to some very fine buildings on the left-hand side.‘It was a problem getting the plan is to agree to the ious shapes and types of materials that were to be used, but we overcame all these things and got the go-ahead.’FIFTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Popular local turf accountant, Mr Hugh McKellar, has won a holiday for two in Majorca in a raffle organised by Tarbert Football Club.Mr McKellar did not even know he had won the prize. For he threw away the tickets he had bought, thinking that the dance at which the winning ticket was to be drawn had been held.But, unbeknown to him, the fuel crisis meant that thewas postponed for a week.When told he had won the prize, Mr McKellar was flabbergasted.‘It was the biggest surprise of my le. And I’ve had a few,’ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Paterson’s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while ships’ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboat’s radio: ‘Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.‘Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.’There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours – ‘St Kentigern Refloated.’The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coaster’s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

title: information is key in kintyre
story: Campbeltown-based Keeping it local CICis introducing the screens up and down the peninsula, including Tarbert and on the Isle of Gigha.A spokesperson for the community interest company said: #With the support of fantastic businesses all over we are able to provide up-to-date information on events, news, travel and destination areas to visit all around the area at the touch of a button.#The work we do is also supported by advertising on our screens while promoting your own business offerings.#The boards should be up and running by April, all being well.The aim of Keeping it local CIC is to support businesses, trades, services and events by collating information and bringing all that Kintyre has to offer under one roof # a one-stop-shop for the consumer and businesses.The Tarbert information boards are due to be located at One Fyne Deli and at The Gather restaurant.

title: island residents and friends have a happy 20th gigha day
story: Celebrations were in full swing this week as residents on the Isle of Gigha marked  years of community ownership.After extensive community fundraising alongside securing grants and loans from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and the National Lottery, Gigha was purchased by the community for the sum of £m on March  .On this day the island was handed over to the Isle of Gigha Heritage Trusta day that is marked on the island every year as #Gigha Day#.To commemorate this -year milestone all Gigha residents and key island stakeholders were invited to watch Gigha’s eldest female resident Ina McNeill raise the island flag on Tuesday.This was followed by a display from the pupils of Gigha Primary School and a performance by the Kintyre Schools Pipe Band, who made the journey over from Campbeltown to attend.The Isle of Gigha Hotel then welcomed the guests for refreshments and to view a display of island memorabilia and photographs from the past  years.Since the buyout the permanent population of the island has grown from around  up to  residents.This has been achieved through housing renovations and new affordable housing, coupled with increased economic development.Gigha has several businesses which support employment on the island and IGHT now employs  people across its office, maintenance team, Achamore Gardens, new campsite, marketing, and ranger service.This includes two apprentices who are contributing to the restoration of Achamore Gardens.The trust is managed by a board of voluntary directors who are elected by the membership to develop the assets of the island and take forward plans and projects for the community.IGHT  retains ownership of the majority of the built and land assets of the island, worth over £m.Since the buy-out in  IGHT has renovated  houses as part of an ongoing investment programme, sold  plots for private self-build development, developed four wind turbines which help fund development, installed moorings and pontoon facilities, successfully marketed Gigha’s tourism assets as well as working to protect and conserve Gigha’s heritage and environment.One of the trust’s biggest challenges has been managing its financial position.The trust’s debt levels increased to £.m in  after taking out loans to deliver housing renovations.This debt burden is now reduced to £,, which has been achieved through asset sales and income from its renewable and trading companies.The trust has a number of projects underway including a new campsite, km of new and upgraded path networks, on-site and online heritage interpretation, five new housing units, and a -year restoration plan for Achamore Gardens.The trust is actively trying to reduce the island#s carbon footprint through  e-bikes for hire from the activity centre and is also soon to install the island#s first electric vehicle charging point.

title: leader march 11 2022 2
story: So the Scottish Government remains adamant in its decision to ban creelers from the Clyde for the next two months or so.We#re not talking North Sea trawlers here that can go where in the interim. We#re talking about small family businesses whose livelihoods depend on them setting their creels in the Clyde.Many have invested heavily in their boats and equipment and have no other options available to them but to sit it out.Many employees of Dawnfresh Seafoods were brought to their knees recently after being denied a week#s wages. Our creel fishermen are having to survive  weeks.Financial compensation is a must and government ministers should now make it a priority to offer this. Before irreversible harm is done.Much has already been said about the rallying of our community to come to the aid of the people fleeing their homes in war-torn Ukraine.But we will keep on saying it.This week it was the efforts from our youngest inhabitants that shone through. From collecting donations to making, drawing and writing messages of hope to their European peers.Keep up the good work, everyone.

title: letters march 11 2022 2
story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.    The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..    The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.    Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..    Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.    To keep the ban in place.    Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Duplicity#s original meaning in English has to do with a kind of deception in which true feelings or intentions are hidden behind  words or actions.I wouldn’t blame the children of South Sudanthey just gave up.One third are suffering chronic malnutrition. Half are missing school. Millions are displaced. And none of them have ever known anything but war.One of my colleagues there, a -year-old man, tells me he has never seen peace in his letime. But he has seen hope. He has witnessed the hope our colourful bowls full of maize and beans bring to some of the poorest children on earth.Mary’s Meals feeds more than two million children every school day in  of the world’s poorest countries.Our nutritious meals attract little ones into the classroom, where they can gain an education that gives them hope for the future.We are already reaching around , hungry children in South Sudan, and – with the support of your readers – we can serve our le-changing meals in even more schools. Please visit marysmeals.org.uk to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan aren’t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: rest campaign seeks uk government help 2
story: That was the message delivered to Iain Stewart, UK Government Minister in Scotland, at a high-powered meeting last week to discuss the Rest and be Thankful.Convened by John Gurr, chair of business-led Rest and be Thankful Campaign, the gathering in the George Hotel included Argyll and Bute chief executive Pippa Milne, council leader Robin Currie, constituency MSP Jenni Minto, regional MSPs Rhoda Grant and Donald Cameron and Brendan O#Hara MP.Among the business representatives were Kenny MacLeod, director of MacLeod Construction Ltd, Duncan McAllister of NFU Scotland, Jane MacLeod of Mid Argyll Chamber of Commerce, Iain Catterwell representing timber haulage, Donna Irwin of Loch Fyne Oysters and Argyll Estates factor Hugh Nicol.Fteen years of disruption on the A at the Rest and be Thankful culminated in two major landslides in August and September .In total the A carriageway at the Rest was closed for  days that year, with a -plus mile detour in place for more than a month.The estimated economic cost to Argyll and Bute in the eight months between August ,  and March ,  was £. million.The road#s unreliability, the minister heard, is a factor in population decline impacts the area#s ability to fund services and hampers Argyll#s ability to attract a workforce and keep local businesses viable.Mr Gurr said: #The A at the Rest has not been fully open without traffic lights since , and traffic continues to be moved to the old military road detour, under traffic lights and convoy, when it rains.#When you drive past at mph, you#re thinking #will I get hit by a landslide#. It#s scary.#In  Transport Scotland selected the #cheapest# option from a  report by Jacobs Engineering. Nine years and £ million later they are still digging.#The Scottish Government has committed to building a #permanent solution# at the Rest, expected to take up to  years to complete. What is not clear is what solution it will adopt and when work will start.While transport is a devolved matter, the meeting on March  was intended to raise awareness within the Scotland Office of the importance of Argyll, and the A, to the UK # and explore any support it could give to speeding up the process.In  the UK Government published a Union Connectivity Report # with Argyll conspicuous by its absence. Mr Stewart was asked whether the region could be added to the list of transport priorities.The minister replied that while #there is no magic wand# he agreed that it was an emergency involving a leline road.He said: #I will be speaking with Scottish Transport Secretary Jenny Gilruth soon. The Rest and be Thankful, and the calls for urgency on the A, will be high on our agenda.#Meanwhile, the UK Government will be looking at whether our Union Connectivity Review, Levelling Up Fund and Shared Prosperity Fund have potential for the Rest and be Thankful.#

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. It’s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. Given the right conditions however, growth is virtually unstoppable. We see that from the way the grass grows week after week.So what are the churches doing to prevent growth  Are they ploughing the same furrow over and over again or are they looking for fresh ways to cultivate interest It’s not easy butwe resist change it’s going to become even harder.Springtime invites us to take a fresh look at things and sharpen up our prospects for the future. We shouldn’t be afraid to look at things afresh.That’s when we discover new ideas. New ideas bring new le. Let’s be positive about the future.

title: its all tickety boo in kintyre
story: Figures obtained by the Local Democracy Reporting Service under the Freedom of Information Act show that Argyll and Bute Council issued  penalty charge notices in its car parks in Mid-Argyll, Kintyre and the Islands during  and .Of those,  – all bar two of them in Inveraray – have yet to be paid.Two of them date from  – one from the Front Street and coffee house car parks in Inveraray and the other in the Lorne Street coach park in Lochgilphead.A further five issued in the Front Street and coffee house car parks in Inveraray during  remain unpaid, along with one each from the Avenue and Fisher Row car parks, also in Inveraray.The other unpaid ticket from  was issued in the Lorne Street parking area in Lochgilphead.The Front Street and coffee house car parks saw by far the most parking tickets given out during the two years, with  in total, while the Avenue was next with .In the nine months after lockdown was imposed in March ,  tickets were issued in in Mid-Argyll, Kintyre and the Islands by the council.Only three were issued between April and the end of July, the majority of which was spent with the country under travel restrictions.Only one was issued in the first three months of , when travel restrictions were again in place.The total of  makes up less than two per cent of the total of more than , parking tickets issued across Argyll and Bute by the council in  and . More than  per cent of those were handed out in Helensburgh and Lomond.A council spokesperson said: #The council follows standard legal procedures for any unpaid penalty charge notices .#If you have a question about a parking fine, contact argyll-bute.gov.uk forms car-park-fine-enquiry-form.

title: liveargyll invite to bring along a mum for mothers day
story: liveArgyll leisure members can claim a member guest pass online and bring along a loved one for free, to celebrate a happy and healthy Mother#s Day together.The member guest pass allows any liveArgyll leisure member to invite a guest to enjoy a free gym or swim session, or even a fitness class.It should be noted those wishing to go to a fitness class together will need to phone Aqualibrium on   to book in advance.Robert Judge, liveArgyll area operations manager for Kintyre and Islay, said: ‘This Mother#s Day, liveArgyll wants to help you thank the important women in your le and encourage you to spend time together, all while boosting your health and fitness.‘If you’re not a member, there’s still plenty of ways you can join in the fun. We will be running public swimming sessions over the weekend, including our popular Family Fun session – floor raised – on Sunday from .pm to .pm, or you could book yourselves in for one of our fitness classes.#However you decide to celebrate, we wish you a happy Mother#s Day and look forward to seeing you.’Visit liveargyll mothers-day-guest-pass to request your member guest pass.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: line-duty-watch-exclusive-ac-12-reunion
story: Martin Compston, Vicky McClure and Adrian Dunbar are reuniting with the writer of the show Jed Mercurio for a "one-off" reunion event in aid of Ardgowan Hospice, where Martin is a patron.The trio, who have been nicking "bent coppers" on screen for a decade, will get together on March  in Port Glasgow Town Hall, close to Martins home in Greenock.All proceeds from the live event will help the local hospice continue its le-changing work in the community.----------------------------The exclusive video will only be available to our subscribers.You can pay as little as £ for your first month and that fee will go directly to Martins favourite charity, Ardgowan Hospice.To sign up, visit our subscribe page here and take advantage of our latest amazing offers.Our exclusive recording of the event will be available to subscribers HERE from Thursday March .For those who already subscribe, you will also receive exclusive access to the video.Subscriptions can be cancelled at any time.If you would like to make a further donation to Ardgowan Hospice, you can do so HERE.

title: schoolchildren-visit-scottish-parliament-first-time-since-pandemic-began
story: Students visited Holyrood as part of the Scottish Parliament’s education visits programme to learn more about the work of MSPs – a trip that was not possible for almost two years due to coronavirus restrictions.Two Higher modern studies classes attended Holyrood last Tuesday and were met by Martin Whitfield and Brian Whittle, South Scotland MSPs.Mr Whitfield, who was previously East Lothian’s MP and a teacher at Dirleton Primary School, was delighted to welcome the pupils to the Capital.He said: “The suspension of public visits to Parliament has been one of many disappointing impacts of the pandemic over the last two years.“It was a pleasure to meet the Knox Academy students and answer some of their questions, and I look forward to welcoming many more young people from other local schools over the course of this parliamentary session.”S pupil Mara Popa described it as “an amazing experience for everyone” and said: “During this time, we were able to ask our MSPs questions about what an MSP does, committees that they are members of, and how they can hold the Government to account.”

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1997-1972-1922
story: THE school bell was ringing for the last time for Dunbar Grammar School’s headteacher, reported the East Lothian Courier on March , .Will Collin today walks through the gates of Dunbar Grammar School for the last time as headteacher.After almost  years in the senior post, and five years before that as assistant head, he is taking early retirement at the age of .Explaining his decision, Mr Collin said: “I feel I am ready for retirement and putting my feet up.”Born and raised in Eyemouth, he began teaching maths and physics at the high school there in .Five years later he moved to Arbroath before coming to Dunbar as assistant headteacher in .Following an -month sojourn as the deputy head of Selkirk High School in the early s, he ed to Dunbar in .Looking back over a career spanning three decades at the school, Mr Collin, who lives with his we Val in Rosebery Place, said: “The best part of the job is working with young people.”...and  years agoVandals created ‘a reign of terror’, told the East Lothian Courier on March , .A wave of vandalism in East Lothian recently was likened to a “reign of terror” by a county official this week.He said damage amounting to almost £, had been done to a pavilion in Prestonpans.“We are fighting a losing battle,” said Mr George B. Ritchie of the architect’s department.“Contractors attempting to re-instate and modernise Preston Lodge School pavilion in Preston Road can’t keep pace with the amount of vandalism there.”...and  years agoA VILLAGE pageant in Cockenzie was the talk of the town, said The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .An artistic and interesting entertainment was given under the auspices of the Girls’ Friendly Society in the U.F. Church Hall.“A Dream of Good Women,” representing dferent periods in a marvellously effective manner, passed before the spectators.The dressing and training of the ious characters called forth the warm appreciation and approval of the audience, and reflected great credit not only on the artistes, but also on the superintendent of the G.F.S., Mrs Howie, who had the greater burden of the work thrown on her shoulders.

title: former-msp-jeane-freeman-queen-margaret-university-role
story: The role will see her contribute to the university’s health projects and “champion” female leadership in the health sector.QMU was in the top  of UK universities for subjects allied to medicine in The Times and The Sunday Times Good University Guide .A QMU spokesperson said: “The school leads the way in ‘person-centred’ approaches to health that have been led by the Division of Nursing and the Centre for Person-centred Practice Research.Professor Jeane Freeman OBE “Professor Freeman has had a long and successful leadership career in the fields of health and social justice, latterly as Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport in the Scottish Government.”Professor Fiona Coutts, dean of the School of Health Sciences, said: “The appointment of Jeane Freeman as honorary professor, an inspiring female leader with key public health experience, is going to bring huge benefits to our education, research and student community.”Sir Paul Grice, vice chancellor and principal of QMU, said: “She brings a rare combination of knowledge, experience and leadership, and I am looking forward very much to working with her at Queen Margaret University.”Professor Freeman commented: “This appointment is a real honour.”

title: new-bike-racks-installed-outside-county-church
story: New bike racks have been installed outside St Anne’s Scottish Episcopal and Methodist Church in a bid to encourage people to cycle more.In a week, about - visits are made to the church for a iety of activities, with hopes the bike racks will encourage people to leave the car at home.Funding for the scheme came from Spare Wheel and Cycling Scotland, with Community Windpower donating £,.A spokesperson for the church said: “The rack will also be available to any cyclists coming to the north end of High Street, where there is a shortage of places to secure bicycles.”

title: haddstock-festival-return-late-spring
story: Haddstock was held in  and  before taking a break in .The last two years were affected by the Covid- pandemic but Rebecca Dover, festival organiser, confirmed the event would be ing.She stressed planning was “at the very, very beginning” but the festival would take place on May -.She said: “We are really looking forward to a live event at the end of May.”

title: sharons-hair-beauty-boutique-voted-among-scotlands-best
story: The glamorous ceremony saw  of the best hair and beauty professionals come together at the DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel in Glasgow to crown Scotland’s finest.Sharon’s Hair and Beauty Boutique on Market Street claimed the award, and was also highly commended in the neighbourhood salon of the year category.The salon was also listed amongst Scotland’s top salons as it continued its tradition of being one of the nation’s best.Sharon Edgar, the salon owner, thanked the loyal customers who nominated her for the award. She said: “We are extremely pleased to have won at these prestigious awards again, especially as the last two years have been such a dficult time in our industry.“We have such a great team at the salon and such wonderful supportive clients who nominate us year after year.“We are overwhelmed to also have been listed in the top-rated salons in Scotland.”A spokesperson for the Scottish Hair  Beauty Awards said: “We would like to congratulate all finalists and winners for their achievements and we hope that they will keep up their amazing work.”

title: letter-week-young-people-need-facilities-now
story: This site was allocated in the council’s approved Local Development Plan as a site for an additional football pitch along with changing facilities. The developer of Hallhill North would also need to pay for the development of the new football pitch and the changing rooms.The planning application also included a play area and open space in front of the primary school. That all has planning approval and work will proceed on site before the summer. However, a group of concerned parents were at the same time looking for a site to locate a skate park and pump track in Dunbar they did a presentation to the community council on their ideas. I have for the last several months been working with these parents and iniduals.We are aware that skateboarding and BMX bikes are now Olympic sports and the idea of linking these facilities with the fantastic sporting facilities we have at Hallhill developed into the idea of locating it on the land we have available at Lochend. We have been developing this idea and, along with the changing rooms, we feel that a community cafe would be fantastic for our young people when they use this area. It would provide some supervision for the area and provide toilets and refreshments for the people using the facility.We are all aware of the anti-social behaviour that has been taking place within our community. Our young people are currently using Lochend Woods at nights and over the weekends to meet up but have no supervision and are getting involved in anti-social behaviour. We see lots of complaints about our young people on social media and now all young people have been banned from using McDonald’s in the evenings. The situation will not improve and will become dangerous unless we do something to support them. We need to provide these young people somewhere they can meet up in a safe area along with some supervision.The outdoor activity can be used by anyone despite their age, sex or ability. I would expect to see adults and children using this facility at the same time along with some quality coaching in all activities. We are fortunate in Dunbar that many of our young people use skateboards, scooters, roller skates and bikes they will all benefit from using this facility. My hope is all our young people can feel this is a place they can come and feel safe and be involved, or just sit in the cafe with friends for a chat.As for the woodland, I am fully committed to doing everything I can to protect it and the wildle within it. We need to find a way of engaging with our young people to respect it and support the work we need to do protect it and its wildle. I hope the new centre will make young people think they are part of the community woodland and will want to be involved.I am committed to delivering this project on the ground quickly, as I did with the Hallhill Sports Complex that was £ million. I have already secured signicant funding to deliver this project soonI am re-elected as a councillor to represent my community.As for a facility at DunBear Park, at present we do not have any land, funding or a proposal and,it comes together, it could be five to  years away, but our young people need facilities now.NormanHampshireLeader, East Lothian Council

title: haddington-pensioner-praises-aldi-staff-saving-pet-mauling-out-of-control-dog
story: Andy Henderson, , and his West Highland terrier Angus were both attacked by an out-of-control Staffie while enjoying a walk in Haddington.Andy, who is currently battling stomach cancer, was dragged to the ground and bitten by the animal as he attempted to save four-year-old Angus from the attack.Workers from the nearby Aldi store rushed to Andy’s aid after hearing his screams for help and managed to fight the dog off before its owner ed and calmly took the animal away.Angus was left covered in blood after suffering puncture wounds to his face and neck and had to be rushed to a local vet for emergency treatment.Andy and we Caroline, , have now been left with a £ vet bill and are appealing for the dog’s owners to come forward.Police Scotland and East Lothian Council have also launched a hunt for the owner of the Staffie following the incident at Haddington Retail Park at about pm on Thursday.Andy, a taxi driver for the past  years, said: “Angus and I were walking past the Aldi store and I saw the Staffie tied up but only by a choke chain.“It must have slipped the chain as the next thing I knew it had jumped on Angus’s back and was growling and biting him.“I tried to grab it but it turned on me and bit me on the hand and dragged me to the ground as I struggled with it.‘Fortunately some guys from the Aldi shop must have heard me shouting as they came running out and tried their best to help us.“Some passers-by also helped and eventually they kicked and punched the dog so hard they managed to get it off us.“I can’t thank the shop staff enough asthey hadn’t jumped in to save us who knows what could have happened.“Angus was covered in blood and we had to rush him straight to the vet where he was cleaned up.“He had cuts and puncture wounds to his muzzle and his neck but we’ve been told he should recover alright.”Andy said after the attack that two men walked out of the Aldi store and grabbed hold of the Staffie before walking off without saying anything.He added: “The two guys just walked off with the dog butthey have anything about them then they should come forward to admit what has happened.“I would hate to think that it might be a child next time.”A Police Scotland spokesperson said: “Around pm on Thursday, March , police received a report of a dog attack at Haddington Retail Park.“Officers spoke to the reporter and gathered more information. Advice and assistance was given and the report has been referred to the local council’s dog warden.”An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: “We are aware of the incident, which is the subject of an investigation with the dog warden.“In addition, this matter has also been raised with the police and we have advised the dog owner who raised the complaint of progress to date.”Aldi has been contacted for comment.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-welcome-back-spectators-popular-easter-saturday-raceday
story: The Betway Easter Saturday, featuring the Queens Cup, is one of the highlights of the sporting calendar in East Lothian and itshas been widely anticipated by racing enthusiasts and those in search of a great day out over the holiday weekend.With racing and entertainment, the East Lothian track will host about , racing fans, who will be able to enjoy an afternoon of racing, street food stalls and ious food and drink options throughout.Easter Saturday, with the highlight the £, Queens Cup, received the royal seal of approval from the Queen herself and will be the feature race of the day.Musselburgh is also delighted to welcome back the team from ITV, who will be covering four races live on ITV Racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: "We are all delighted to welcome our racing fans back to the course."We haven’t been able to allow race-goers to Easter Saturday for the past two years, and as its one of our major flagship races of the year, we are thrilled to provide a destination for couples, friends, families and groups looking for an Easter get-together with a dference."Chad Yeomans, Betway’s head of communications and PR, added: "The Betway Easter Saturday fixture is a great meeting that in  will see theof racing fans to Musselburgh Racecourse."The Betway Queen’s Cup is the feature race on the card and is a great staying handicap, while the Betway Holyrood Handicap promises a competitive dash over five furlongs."Youngsters  and under get free entry to the event when accompanied by a paying adult. There will be a dedicated kids zone, including theof the popular Easter Bunny, free game stalls, free fairground rides for all ages and free face painting.Tickets for the race meetings are on sale now, with an advanced adult offer available to purchase until midnight on April , to save £pp.For the full range of ticket information, visit musselburgh-racecourse tickets easter-saturday---

title: national-lottery-players-get-free-charge-national-museum-flight-weekend
story: To say thank you for the £ million raised for good causes every week by players, the National Lottery is offering free entry and special offers at a range of National Lottery funded venues across the UK as part of the National Lottery Open Week.On Saturday and Sunday, the National Museum of Flight is offering free entry to National Lottery players.Visitors to the museum should book a timed entry ticket online in advance of their visit and bring along both their admission ticket and lottery ticket or scratch card.Steve McLean, general manager at the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune, was looking forward to welcoming visitors.He said: “We’re delighted to be taking part in the National Lottery Open Week this year.“We’re grateful to have received National Lottery funding, which has enabled us to redevelop two of our nationally signicant Second World War hangars.“Devoted to military and civil aircraft, they explore a century of aviation, presenting the stories of some of the people who built and flew them.“This is our way of saying thank you to everyone who has bought a National Lottery ticket, helped us on our journey and made a contribution to supporting good causes.”

title: work-start-dunbar-uniteds-new-stand
story: Work is due to start at the club’s New Countess Park within a matter of weeks, ahead of the -seater stand being put in place there.The club hopes that the stand will be ready for the start of the new East of Scotland Football Leagueseason kicking off later this summer.Fans have increasingly got behind Kevin Haynes’ team, who currently sit th out of  teams in the Premier Division, the top flight of the EoSFL, this season.The club enjoyed a memorable debut in the Scottish Cup this season, defeating Broxburn Athletic and Camelon Juniors before losing out to Lothian Thistle Hutchison Vale in the second round.Stuart Robertson, the club’s chairman, said: “It is unbelievable.“We have almost quadrupled our gate income from times before Covid, which is a big testament to how the community has got behind us this season.“We have made a huge effort as a board to be more inclusive.“The Scottish Cup has been helpful and created a buzz.“We had nearly , people to those matches as part of the Scottish Cup campaign.”Work has gone on in the background for a number of years to see a stand erected down the western touchline at New Countess Park.Planning permission is already in place and Mr Robertson confirmed that an order for the -seater stand had now been placed.Local firm AG Thomson will carry out the groundwork before the stand is in place in time for the new season.The club’s chairman took time to praise the community, who had once again got behind the club with about £, raised through a sponsor-a-seat campaign.He said: “I think that New Countess Park is already a top-end facility in the region but this makes it stand out as the best in the region.“There are better in the league, like Linlithgow Rose, but certainly not in East Lothian.“It is all about seeing the other clubs improving all the time and we want to be part of it.“As well as having got the SFA licence last year, this was the next step for the board.“A lot of our fans cannot stand for two hours and hopefully this adds to a really strong following we have got this season.”Eve Coaches, which is the club’s shirt sponsor, has also agreed a -year sponsorship deal on the new stand.The season is due to come to an end on May , when Dunbar head for Tynecastle, but Mr Robertson revealed there were already “high-profile friendlies in the pipeline” to mark the completion of the new stand ahead of the beginning of the   campaign.

title: young-haddington-footballers-send-kits-nigeria
story: A second shipment of training kit, match strips and football boots has been donated by players and families from Haddington Athletic’s youth section.Nandom Domyil, a striker in Nigeria, attended the club’s Whittingehame Drive facility earlier this month as the kit was packed up ready to be sent to his homeland.Nandom also took on the role of guest coach as he put the Hi Hi’s  squad through their paces.The donations are being sent to Greatway Academy Football Club in Lagos – a club previously represented by Nandom and now a youth partner of Haddington Athletic.Nandom, , recently enrolled in a master’s degree at Heriot-Watt University.He said: “I have come to Scotland to pursue my studies and I am only too happy to help Haddington in this way as a thank you for the generosity of the parents and players of the club.“I also want to continue playing football during my stay and am actively seeking a club to join.”

title: cockenzie-port-seton-kids-receive-jubilee-coin
story: The major jubilee celebrations will begin on June  and continue through the weekend until June .Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council announced that, thanks to the generosity of local iniduals and organisations, everyone aged  and under living in the area will receive a diecast commemorative coin.To register to receive the coin, residents should fill out a form at spanglefish cockenzieandportsetoncommunity news.aspNames must be received by March  to ensure they are included in the order.

The supermarket giant had installed netting in the roof space of its North Berwick store, removing and sealing about  house martin nests.The migratory birds willin the coming weeks and the protest hoped to pressurise Tesco into removing the netting in time for the endangered species.The peaceful protest was organised by Carole Fairhurst and included those of all ages out to show their anger at Tescos decision.Carole was delighted at the turnout and how the people of North Berwick had come together to protect the animals.She said: "I think there were about  people there of all dferent ages."There was people passing by in their cars, tooting their horns in support, acknowledging they were on board."She added thatthe protest wasnt enough to convince Tesco to change its policy then residents were going to boycott the supermarket until it removed its preventative netting.Jacq Cottrell, Scottish Greens candidate for the North Berwick Coastal ward at Mays East Lothian Council elections, was also present at the protest and agreed that a boycott might have to be the next stage.She had suggested implementing a no Tesco hour where people would avoid using the store and get the message across.She said: "You would have a time where we would persuade as many people in the town as possible not to shop at Tesco."We can make it really clear that there is a strong objection to this amongst the local community and I think that would be a great way of communicating that quite clearly."We are envisaging quick next steps to put up the pressure on Tesco to do something."

title: new-laws-using-mobile-phone-car
story: Tougher limits are coming in for drivers when using mobile phones at the wheel.Handling a phone or mobile device, whether checking notications, checking the time or unlocking the device, will be banned under the new rules which come into force on March .Drivers caught breaking the new rules could face a £ fine or six points on their licence.This is everything you need to know about the new rules.Drivers will not be able to:The only exceptions to the new rules are when making an emergency callit is not possible to stop or pull over, or to make a contactless payment at a toll or drive-thru.Using your phone as a sat nav will still be allowed as long as it is secured in a holder.Hands free calls will also be allowed.Edmund King, AA president, said: “The AA has long campaigned to toughen up these rules, and we welcome this announcement.“This is a much needed upgrade of the law to help make our roads safer. Mobile phones offer many distractions and this sends a clear message that picking them up to use them will not be tolerated.“The law will also become tougher as the use of smartwatches, tablets and laptops behind the wheel will apply.“Drivers will be extremely limited on when they can pick up their phone, mainly to call the emergency services when there was no opportunity to safely pull over and to make contactless payments at drive-thrus."Being sat in a traffic jam or waiting at the lights is not an excuse, we want people to keep their hands on the wheel and their eyes on the road.”

title: sky-reveals-new-content-coming-channels-now-april
story: With a iety of new and ing content named in the list, April could be a busy month of TV for Sky viewers.Here’s the list of Sky and NOW content we’re excited to be able to watch in April." alt"East Lothian Courier: Sky TV remote and TV guide " class"editor-image"Sky TV remote and TV guideA Sky Original that you’ll be able to watch on Sky Max and NOW from Friday April .You’ll see character Neve Kelly investigate her own death after she has died. She’ll uncover secrets and re-examine her le. Crime fans might recognise that this is an adaptation of Belgian crime thriller Hotel Beau Séjour.A Sky Original you’ll be able to watch on Sky Max and NOW in April.Well known sport stars, Freddie Flintoff and Jamie Redknapp, embark on yet another road trip. Guests including Romesh Ranganathan, Tyson Fury, Patrice Evra, Maisie Adam, Alan Carr, Tom Davis will join the pair taking on challenges while travelling through the British and Emerald Isles. The trip will start in Ireland.Available to watch via Sky Witness and NOW from Wednesday April .Part  of the th series saw some of Grey Sloan Memorial’s doctors in trouble after a car crash. Now Meredith Grey tries to save Dr Hamilton’s le while the doctors deal with the aftermath of the crash." alt"East Lothian Courier: A box of popcorn and a TV remote " class"editor-image"A box of popcorn and a TV remoteThe Sky Glass team has put together a list of new things you should know about your Sky Glass.Formula  is now shown in High Dynamic Rangefor the first time in its history. Say “Hello Sky, Formula ”, to access the latest news and analysis from Sky Sports F and F shows.The Audio and Music Zone uncovers sounds from Sky shows and YouTube, Disney+, Netflix and more. The Spoty app gives you your favourite music via Party Mode and adds lyrics for a singalong.: Sky Glass: Buy the smartest TV available from just £ per month: Sky launches new superfast broadband package - How to sign upAdd speaker fascias, available to buy on Amazon here. They come in dferent sizes and the patterns are inspired by nature including: Ocean blue, Marble, Jade plus more.Until Friday May , Sky VIP Glass customers can stream Apple TV+ for free for  months by signing up to Sky VIP.Sky Marketplace allows you to sign up to Disney+ straight from the Sky UI and pay for your subscription with your card details when you say “Hello Sky, Get Disney Plus”.If you arent already signed up to Sky but would like to join, you can visit the Sky website here. TV and other deals are displayed on Skys website, helping you choose which package suits you best.

title: north-berwick-schoolgirls-finish-second-investment-contest
story: Keira Maynard, Bethan Ryan and Marcia Callander represented the school in the Growing Future Assets Competition, designed to encourage more women into the industry and foster new talent.They faced stf competition from schools across the country, eventually finishing second in the - category behind Lochaber High School from Fort William.The S girls were delighted at their achievement and all the experience they gained as a result of the competition.They said: “We really enjoyed getting an insight into the world of investment and are inspired to continue to find out more.“Working closely with our mentor Amanda was massively helpful she supported us with the financial aspect of the competition and gave great presentation tips, which will give us a competitive edge in our future careers.“The Growing Future Assets Competition has given us unparalleled knowledge we otherwise wouldn’t have had, and we would encourage young people curious about business and finance careers to get involved in the future.”For their efforts, they won £ for the school and £ vouchers for themselves.Hannah Fox, business education teacher at North Berwick High School, shared in their delight and said that the girls had gained a valuable insight into the investment industry.She said: “The competition offers more than a chance to gain an insight into the investment industry via task completion it opens doors to valuable industry mentors and opportunities for work place visits.“It is genuinely the most valuable educational competition I’ve worked on and would not hesitate to recommend it to educational peers.”

title: memories-musselburghs-manufacturing-past
story: The initiative – ‘Made in Musselburgh: Memories of Industry in the Honest Toun’ – is aimed at preserving knowledge of an important part of the town’s past.An open drop-in event will be held at Stuart House, Eskmills, on Wednesday, March , from am to pm, when residents will hear how they can get involved.A project spokesperson said that the manufacturing industry was a prominent employer in Musselburgh for many years.Brunton’s Wire Mill made wire for musical instruments and ropes.During the First World War, the Air Ministry relied on the company for the manufacture of aeroplane wires.Production was again focused on military manufacturing during the Second World War, including bomb slings, aeroplane cables and fittings, ropes for many purposes, and whip aerials.In the s and s, the firm continued to specialise in aircraft wings and fittings.One growing area of supply at this time was in bridge ropes, and the company made all of the wire ropes used in the construction of the Forth Road Bridge, and the suspension ropes for the Humber Bridge.In February , Brunton’s closed, ending  years of wire manufacture in the town.J  W Stuart Mills became a world leader in the fishing net industry, with sales and repair facilities in North America, Europe and Australia.Colonel James Paterson, local to Musselburgh, invented and patented in  the first machine capable of tying knots for the manufacture of fishing nets.When he died, his company and patents for knot-tying machines were bought by J.W. Stuart, who established a factory for the manufacture of fishing nets on the banks of the River Esk.Inveresk Paper Mill was another of Musselburgh’s past industries, built by Alex Cowan and Sons of Valleyfield in .The paper manufacturer specialised in fine writing, printing and art papers.The mill closed in  and was mostly demolished.The council-operated John Gray Centre in Haddington, which holds local archives, and the European Ethnological Research Centre , from the University of Edinburgh, are working to record the memories of local people.Mark Mulhern, senior research fellow at the EERC, explained: “Hearing from the folk of Musselburgh about their memories of its industrial manufacturing past will greatly enrich our understanding of the Honest Toun.”Ruth Fyfe, archivist with East Lothian Council, said: “We have a fantastic collection of images in the archives relating to the wire, net and paper mills in Musselburgh so this is a great opportunity to come along and see them.“We’re excited to be part of the project. ”part of the project. The recordings will be available to the public and preserved in our archives for generations to come so this really is a chance to be involved in making Musselburgh’s history."

title: new-gym-set-macmerry-industrial-estate
story: East Lothian Council has granted planning permission for the units to be built south of the A.Crossfit Haddington, Hickory Food and Edinburgh Plant Hire are set to take the premises.Planning permission is in place for one of the units to be used as a fitness centre, while the other two are designated as being for storage and distribution.: Tranent gym plans given the green lightA car park with  spaces, and a further three spaces for disabled users, will be created.There were no objections to Merryfield IC Ltd’s proposals.

title: another-149-new-homes-wallyford-now-offered-sale
story: Housebuilder Taylor Wimpey East Scotland said it had launched phase two of its Ravensheugh development following the "success" of phase one.Interested homebuyers can book an appointment to chat to the local sales executive and browse the selection of two, three and four bedroom homes available.A "range of options for first-time buyers and growing families", was highlighted by the company, with prices starting from £, for the Drummond four-bedroom detached home.The wider St Clements Wells masterplan has seen a new Wallyford Primary School opened at Futures Way, while a new secondary school is currently being built.A local centre and community woodland, along with new foot and cycle connections to Wallyford and the village’s train station, are also proposed.East Lothian Council,
